sp.p: By what accident came you to that power? have you seen her since?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No, but this place is too publick; let's retire, and you shall know all; and when I would my Sister know, I'll read her through thy observations; but here let thy interest give way to my love.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I shall obey, Sir.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. III.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: MY thoughts can find no rest; Love, wilt thou not quit me in Prison? art thou covetous of my chains too? Fool! hast thou not miseries enough of thine own? And yet I ought not to revile him; for he that hath fill'd my heart is full of honour, and could he guess my fate, I know he would quit a Crown, as a burthen, and seek a freedom in these chains. The Gods are just, to let me fall into these miseries, that we may taste what 'tis our ambition imposes upon others, guilty only as I was, by being too weak.—Whose that? come in; Prisoners keep One knocks. no doors.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, I come to tell you, our Captain has refused to sell me your freedom, and to morrow is the Mart at Naples; But if you dare trust him, whose misfortunes have made him appear your enemy, I'll gage a life to save your honour, and give you freedom. The plot is already laid, and those that were taken with you I have already acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I shall willingly obey any directions, without a thought of fear, for sure there's no condition below this.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: I will not now dispute this misfortune, but remedy it if I can; know, to morrow (lest the accident surprize you ere we put to sea) I have so ordered, that all the slaves that row in the Galley shall be loose, the Captain is my creature, and my self will still wait upon you, and be your guard; but be pleased to sit still when the word is given, and let us work your fate; But once free, command Cilius where you please, your friends too shall privately be arm'd.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, what to say in return of this, I know not, and if you that can be thus gallant, thus good, cannot likewise from that honour that directs you now, find a reward, I fear you will lose this good deed.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: It is a debt all honest men owe your virtue; and I but obey my genius, for I know not what it is, but something whispers to my soul, and bids me serve you, and when my life can purchase you a good, you shall not need command it; I beseech you no reply, a Souldiers prayers (that seldom importunes heaven) I hope will protect you.—

div.stage: [Enter Lieu. and meets them as they are going out.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: How now, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I should speak with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, I'll wait upon you straight.—Are they all ready?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I have done it, they are all resolv'd, I gave them their lives for it; and let him swear when he sees them there, 'tis no matter: they are all loose and arm'd, their chains are but for shew.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: No matter for his rage, let him storm; once aboard, we are masters, for he's but one, and what's a General without obedience? his power we give, and if a multitude knew their own strength, who can command that beast?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I'll away, and send the other Galleys off before, lest they assist him.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Be faithful, and I'll make thee fortunate.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Sir, never fear it, I have said it, and I'll do it; he that refuses to be a knave for a handsome woman, may he dye honest, and be executed for a knave.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Where's the Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Here, Sir, I have waited this hour for you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, shall we go see the sick man?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I'll follow you, Sir.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Enter Tullius, sick in his Bed, a Souldier with him, and Drums beating.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: NO rest! no ease! O miserable, miserable riches! some drink, O, some drink, ere this thirsty flame hath licked up all my life, meat, any thing to satisfie this wolf here.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Have patience, it cannot last above a day or two, about which time I hope to see you quit of all the troubles of this world.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Let me sleep then, quiet those Drums, that I may dream of meat and drink; is there nothing to eat, no drink? oh misery of miseries!—Who's there? One knocks.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: The Captain, Sir, and Lieutenant are come to see you.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Is it they? not a word then that I am hungry or thirsty, I'll buy thy silence at any rate.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now, how is this sick man, where is he?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: He has vomited such stuff, since the Lieutenant went; sure, that your worship gave him was good against an Impostume.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: By this good day, the same water that eat Crabb's knife; what shall we do with this Rogue? a hole in his side, big enough to creep in at, will not kill him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let's speak with him.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Who's there? my noble Captain, and kind Lieutenant; thank you for this visit; truly, it joys me to see you both here, and He takes the Capt. by the hand. He sits up in his Bed. specially my noble Captain; And I am pretty lusty on the sudden; and I'll do what I do not use to do, I'll begin a health to my noble Captain, that he may see he is welcome; do'st hear honest friend, fetch a bottle of Sack, I'll even drink it, come what will after it, and my friend there shall pledge me; and do'st hear, reach me one They sit down by his Bed-side. of the Gammons of Bacon out of the Chimney, it may be my Captain has a stomack,—If he has not, I'm sure I have.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am glad to find you thus merry, and so resolv'd; 'tis the part of a good man to prepare and dye cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I told you, you would find him well prepar'd; and what think you, is not Sack and Bacon better then Barley-water and soak'd Chickens?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: I confess, I was a fool then, but now I'll pledge you all the Sack I refus'd then; and to let my Captain see I resolve to dye, and serve him, look you but on, and I'll eat all the Gammon alone, but you must not tell the Physitian.

div.stage: Enter the Souldier with the Wine, Bacon, a great Bottle, a Napkin and Bread.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Give me a knife and some Bread, fill, fill a bowl of Sack, and bring it hither. Lord! Captain, you would not think how it Tull. sings. rejoyces me to see all this good company here.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am beholding to you; fill, fill the sack.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Help to set me up. They offer to give him the Sack.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Hold, give me the Cup; I'll begin a health to the sick man.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: No, pray give me leave to begin my noble Captain's? pray, pray let me begin it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: No faith, I'll begin.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Pray drink to me then. He sings again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, you are very merry.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: A Flincher,—Two draughts to one Cup?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: This wine was musty, taste it.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p:
Let me taste it, it may be 'twas an ill bottle, the wine's
good wine, admirable wine. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Give me a bowl, I'll pledge it with a better will, because I see you do not desire it should succeed.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas! I desire to live but till I have drunk your health; To me good Captain, I'll pledge it with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I hope so, I should take it ill to have you refuse me, for any nice scruple of your health.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: As you did me, and cry, a Beer-grass would kill you.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas, I was a fool then, but now I am very desirous to redeem that fault; To me good Captain, your wine cools. As the Capt. goes to drink the Lieu. stops him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Your hat Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh! it's true.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Nay, pray drink, and spare your Complement.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Prithee give me a bit of that Gammon, to taste my Wine with.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Pray help him and me too, I would fain taste whether it be as good as the last was.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes faith, 'tis good, here Crab.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Nay pray let me drink to Crab.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, by my faith, it shall go round.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Let me taste, was not your Wine musty too?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Here's none. Turns the Cup.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Fill, fill Crab, and drink to me, for I long to do thee reason, and begin my Captains. He gives Tullius a piece.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: It's an excellent Gammon, taste.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Some more, pray, to taste.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Where shall I carve you?

sp.speaker: Tul,
sp.p: Any where, any where.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Sir, here's your Wine; will you pledge your health?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p:
So, so, now I am happy; Noble Captain, a thousand times
Crab gives Tulius the Cup.
As he goes to drink the Lieutenant takes hold of the Cup.
I thank you, and with all my heart I'll pledge you.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Hold, a pox take you, Crab, for a couzening Rogue, you have put water in't.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: No, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: No, by my life.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Let me taste, I'll not trust you.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Why taste, Noble Lieutenant; oblige me so far, as to let me drink my own health; nay Lieutenant, Noble Lieutenant. The Lieutenant takes the Cup and drinks up all.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Now, was it not pure?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Hup! by my Faith it was pure indeed; here fill it again, give him a Brimmer.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: I pray never spare me, Lieutenant, you were somewhat harsh the last time you were here, but I'll drink to you.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: I was angry then, because you refus'd to pledge me; but now you'll drink, I am your Friend.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: The Wine, where's the Wine?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Here's none left Sir, shall I fetch another bottle?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Is all gone?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: All gone?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Go fetch another, for he shall pledge me, this trick shall not serve's turn.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Pledge me, alass, Sir, rather then my life I'de pledge you.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: No, no, thou shalt not; faith Captain he's now good natur'd, spare him; it will but make him sick; and troth he's an honest fellow when he is himself.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He shall pledge me.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Alass, Sir, when we are sick, the best of us are unreasonable sometimes.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Lieutenant, Noble Friend.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: I warrant thee, pray Sir let me excuse him for this time, he shall kiss the Cup onely.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: I swear I'll drink it, not pledge my Captain, and 'twere present death I'de do it, fetch some Wine?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, then I'll pardon you; for since I find you willing, I'll excuse your weakness.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Let the Wine alone, Crab.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Spare your thanks. They offer to go away.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: You know the Captain loves no Complements.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Farewell. Thank you for my Wine.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Captain.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Farewell, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Captain, one word before you go.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's the news?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Pray let me drink; for the truth is, I must either eat and drink or die.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How's that? and would you drink and live?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Why thou impudent Rogue; yesterday it was, if I drink I die, now some drink or you are dead.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay then he shall not drink, is this your professions?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, I see you'r resolv'd I must die; let me but have my fill, and I'll die tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Why, faith, it is but abstaining till tomorrow, and then you are sure of it.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: And is it not all one how I die, so I be dead tomorrow? if it be alike to you, pray let me choose; for if Surfeit or Famine can but kill, pray let me surfeit.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am indifferent how, so it be done.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Call me spade if it be not.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: And look we have no Equivocation, but see you be dead tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I fear he will prove a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: I hope you would not desire that I should lay violent hands upon my self.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Marry the Gods forbid, lay violent hands upon thy self; no, no, now you have consented, I'll get one shall do it for you.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Give me some drink, and do what you will with me afterwards.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Set the Vessel by him.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: But is it Sack, Lieutenant? is it Sack? excuse me if I be punctual too?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Give him a Bowl. Tullius drinks.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Give me another, give me a third.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Farewell, Farewell, look you be dead to morrow, or by these hilts I'll apply my Dagger to thy side, and that will be a certain cure; come, Sir, will you please to go?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Captain, Captain, stay a little and see me die, give me another Tullius is drunk. Cup.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By this light, the Rogue is drunk.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Now do I not see any Reason, why I should die.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But I shall give you a Reason to morrow.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: To die with all this Sack about me! No, I am immortal, let those die that are dry.—Hum, give me my sword.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come leave him, he is drunk.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: How now, what would'st you have? As they go away, be rises out of his bed and reeles after them to the door.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: You'll give me leave to wait on my Captain down?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No Ceremony, good Tullius, no Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: It shall be yours Captain, indeed it shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Alass, Sir, give him leave to take cold.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, if it must be so, I obey.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Nay, why Lieutenant, what do you take me for? how do you think I have been bred?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Remember to morrow.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Remember to morrow, let to morrow remember me.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: THis is the Place, Love be thou propitious, and let my fears prove false; hereabout should be the door.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: It is true, I have promis'd him, when he comes, to deliver you; but he has vow'd to use you with Honour, do you not know him?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: No Madam, this is the first time I ever saw him.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Pray what Country claimes your Birth?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Greece, Madam.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Pray grow not in Love with your griefs, but give some part of 'em to me, that now but begin to be sad.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Why should you be sad, that know no grief of Mind? have you lost Friends? or forfeited Freedom?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Fair one, I am more a slave then you; for I am bound by faults, and none can set me free; your miseries are but for a time, and I can release 'em, and yet cannot command my own Fate.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What strange misery can you apprehend? do you love unfortunately?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: No, I love happily, but I have fallen unfortunately, and no length of dayes can set a period to my misery; I love, but cannot hope a return, for I should hate him I love if he could love me; yet, as his Honour forbids him that, and me all hopes to enjoy him, so if he be a perfect Man he hath Mercy too, and he may pity and forgive, though not love Paulina.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: I would ask another Question, but that I am afraid it would search too near your griefs; dare you trust me with the knowledge who it is you love? can I serve you?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: You must not, and therefore cannot, for it is the stranger that fought for you. When first my Eye met his, it shot a flame in here, and the nobleness of that Act (which was sacrific'd to you) shook me, and waked my sleeping Honour, and I began to find desires that till then were strangers here, for they had more of love then blood in them.—What's the business? One knocks.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: There's a young fellow without desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Your pardon.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I have spoil'd your sport if all hit right.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: MAdam, I come from that stranger that this morning your Charity preserv'd, what directions do you command me in his affairs of Love!

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome, and from him all is so; This night I would desire him meet in the garden, where he shall receive her.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I must beg the favour to speak with that Lady, I have a message to impart to her.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: You shall command any thing my power can serve you in, there she comes, and I'le wait upon you straight.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What shall I say to her? my joys have rob'd me of my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: It is he that this morning nam'd me in the street.—Sir, have you any commands for me?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: No Madam, I come to serve, if you'le please to enjoyn; and though a poor Sicilian, yet I know what duty all that wretched Nation owes your Excellence.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Me Sir! sure you mistake.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: No, Madam, I cannot mistake, nor can any miseries so cloud your Beauties, but through all the Innocency and Majesty of such a Princess will appear; sure you will not deny the name of Cicilia? She looks about her.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: To you, Sir, I will not, yet I conjure you to conceal me, and let me know to whom I stand endebted for this Civil opinion.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p:
My name is not worth your knowledge, but my fortunes
I boast of, for I had the honour to be a Souldier, and a Prisoner with your Princely Brother, and fell with him the same day when we lost the battel at Siracusa.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Who, Facertes? where is he, at Rome! Oh, tell me how do's he bear the Insolence of that unworthy Conquerour? It is many years since I saw that beloved Brother, did he never speak of me?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I have often heard him mention you with Tears, and like a Brother give your Character to the fair Sophia, sister to Virgilius, who saved his Life when he was doom'd to the hook.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: The Hook? Oh, ye powers, why do you let this wicked Tyrant thus triumph o're our miseries? But for Virgilius, that false seed of the old Tyrant, that's young and false, and cruel in his youth, let him find some curse, strange as his wickedness.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Madam, upon my life, you injure him; for, my soul to pawn, he loves your Brother: and had no share in that guilty Triumph, for he was then in Gallia.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Oh, thou art deceiv'd, he envies my Brother, and cannot love; and when he could not by force conquer him, by falshood he sought his ruine.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I perceive, Madam, you are a stranger to the Prince's affairs at Rome.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: What are they? new miseries?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Have you not heard how, at the Triumph, the fair Sophia and he, in a look, chang'd hearts, and that now he has his freedom?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: No, this is the first time that I heard of it.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Madam, I saw him free; and (by his friendship with Virgilius) 'tis hoped he shall marry the Princess Sophia: But this is a secret I dare not give to any ear but your own.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: My Brother and Virgilius friends? 'tis false, it must be false, I know he is too much my Brother to make a Friendship there.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: His Love to the Sister, and her merits, who has a virtue equal to her Beauty, made him forget the injuries which Virgilius (in ambitious honour, not malice) threw upon him; besides, it will be a guard for Sicily hereafter, and Facertes gains his ends upon them.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Pray no more of this discourse; I hope my Brother has no ends beyond his Honour; it cannot be he should forget mine and his own injuries, or so bury a Brothers and a Fathers loss; but if absence can do all this, yet his Honour is with him, and that may tell him how glorious, in story, a Slave appears, whilst he keeps his Honour; and how mean and poor that Prince is that sells it for his passion.

sp.speaker: Facertes,
sp.p: Excellent Maid—Madam, I am sorry my discourse displeas'd you.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I would I were with him, or I would I could but write to him.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Madam, if you'le please to write, I'le deliver it him.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p:
No, Sir, that would be too great a trouble, for I believe,
those Occasions which drew you hither are of more consideration then a letter.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: None of such importance as to serve my Prince; 'Tis true, I have a Comrade, a Prince that has disguis'd himself into that condition, and is resolved, under that private habit, to see the world; a scurvy Accident befel him to day, upon the Mole, at the Slaves Mart, where he 'scaped hardly with his life; some wounds he has too, which will retard him, I fear, till my return.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Was it not this morning? a young man, brown-hair'd?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Yes, it was about a slave he saw, and fell in love with; and while he stay'd for money to redeem her, another bought her; I was not at the beginning, but, I thank my fate, I came time enough to his Rescue.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Is he safe then?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, but so impatient, for fear some violence should be offer'd to her, I am now going in search of her; for I know he'le find no Peace, till he has gain'd her freedom.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Is he a Prince, say you, and in love with that Slave?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and now his soul labours in pain, to know what condition she is of; but I hope his flame is made of young mens fire, such as will not last.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Why do you hope so?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Because I have the honour to be his friend; and though I serve his passion, yet I should be loath to see him continue his Love for a Slave, that has nothing but miseries for his Honour to work upon.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: A Prince! then all my Prayers fall not to the Earth, nor lose their way 'twixt heaven and my miseries.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Your prayers, Madam? how, under pardon, are you concern'd in his love or birth?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: You are a Souldier, and by your honour I conjure you; you are a Sicilian, and now Ile take the power you gave, and command you; or by my Brother and his friendship I enjoyn you.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What, Madam?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing; ye gods! whither am I falling? down, She stops and turns from him. down Woman; All the pleadings of my Sex be gone, I will not be a slave to my Passion.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Nor will I be so rude as to press a Secret from you; yet your Brother, Madam, should not serve you more faithfully, nor more willingly, then I.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I must not, no, I will not; yet I durst tell you, but 'tis not like Cicilia, nor the Laws that she has ever followed.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Madam, your name has given Laws, and Cicilia's Acts have ever stood Examples, as unquestioned as unimitable: and by your self, I beg this trust.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Then, as you are a Souldier, take it, and protect it, (I know no guilt,) why should I fear? I was that slave he fought for; and I rejoyce, the man I honour is so favoured of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p:
O Madam, this is a blessing beyond my hopes; dare you trust me to discover who you are? I'le first sound whether his Love
aim with honour, and by degrees work upon him till I have found the secrets of his heart; he shall despair too, and in fear spend some days; But at length dare you not let him know there is a hope? pray leave it to me, I'le see all the Laws of Love observ'd, he shall doubt, and hope, and you shall defer his Joys; But still She walks and looks down: he follows her. I'le wish your Love may increase too, for I know he'le deserve it.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Sir, I have not said I love, nor will not, till I hear him say so first; I confess I hope he loves, and what that hope can be call'd I acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Then all my Joys are full—Nay, my Sister, you must not turn away.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Sister?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Did I say Sister?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Yes, and if my Ears abuse me not, this morning you call'd me sister.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p:
Then I'le hide my self no longer from thee; and since you could confess to a stranger you hop'd he loved, I claim so
He pulls off a patch from his eye.
He shews her a Ring. much trust as to confess you love; will this satisfie you who I am? I mean to give it to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Oh, my Brother, why did you hide your self from me? is it true you told of your self? are you in love? shall not I know your story, that I may rejoyce in your joys?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Thou shalt know all, but let me not now defer the Prince's joy, who waits without and suffers in the doubts which longing love brings.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: The Prince without? is that a truth? pardon me, for since you have deceiv'd me once, it is lawful to suspect.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Yes, and there is another truth which I durst not discover till thy love warranted it me: But now know the man thou hated'st is the man thou lovest; for Virgilius is that Prince; but when thou hast made an acquaintance with him thou wilt confess thy ignorance only could hate him.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Virgilius, then I am miserable!

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Do not say so, but take a Brothers knowledge of him, I have tryed him, friend and enemy, and by both find him pure; and I conjure you, give me your griefs, and believe my love before your hate of the man you love.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Is it Virgilius then?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: By thy self, it is he.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Swear not, unworthy; witness the Gods, that saw and piti'd not my griefs, with what pain I lost thee; yet that was nothing, compar'd to this affliction, that finds thee thus; Go boast to thy friend, what success thy treachery, assisted by a Brothers interest, has gain'd upon a Sister, o'recome with misery.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Why do you accuse me thus? have I injur'd you? is it a fault, to tell you your opinion wrongs a gallant man?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p:
Were he a God, and his friendship of so sovereign a nature, it would protect us against their rods, when with a plague they make a curious search amongst men: were he this, yet, in thee and me 'twere sin to sacrifice to him; and I would sooner oppose that
plague which only wounds my mortal part, then meet Virgilius as a friend.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Why do you conclude me so unworthy, as to call him friend without a satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Thou art not Facertes; he knows there can be no satisfaction: did he not ruine our Country? fell not my aged Father under a Roman sword? is not Lucius, our Brother, lost? and his Ghost still wandring for want of Funeral Rites: But if thou art Facertes, remember how his falshood let thee adorn a triumph; but these are past. Am not I this day sold a slave? do's not our Country still bleed; and whil'st we talk, the licens'd lust of the common Souldier add new crimes? Oh! my Brother, let me not have reason to repent that neerness, but learn to hate him; and while he is in our power take a brave revenge; that he would do something to redeem these faults is no Argument to prefer him before your Country; and though it be gallant in him to love, yet in thee or me a low mean sin.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Had he not said all this, had he not condemn'd himself, I had done it; but when I see his youth soul-sick with love, and full of despairs, ready to sacrifice himself to redeem the misfortunes of a conquest (which he was but a servant in) I must tell Cicilia, when he leaves thus to be an enemy, I must be a friend, for I scorn to hate what loves me; but he loves thee, and to destroy him now is murder, and not revenge.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: That he loves I owe him nothing, for it was chance and fate; and that I love him will be no guard: if I did not love him, 'twere easie to destroy the thing I hate; but it shall be my glory, through my love and loss of peace, to find revenge.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: But his love was no chance; this journey we design'd by the counsel of his Sister, whose interest pleads here, and we were bound for Sicily, and his intents were to heal, by marriage, the wounds you thus lament in our Country; and if now you destroy this means of peace, you have ruin'd it; Cicilia has destroy'd her Country, and to obey her passion wilfully sacrificed our freedom.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Still thou blowest new fires; were your designs for Sicily and me? what has rendred me so cheap to my Brothers thought, as to believe I would receive such a visit from a vain swoln Conqueror, promising to himself success? But he shall find I dare, and can scorn him; and now if I had all the passions that our sex ever yet sunk under, I'de forbid him to my self; and he and you shall find Cicilia's mind not subject to his conquest.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Women, when they have said they are angry are half revenged; and friends, when they have avowed a quarrel. I know her soul full of softness, however her fortune makes this war betwixt her nature and her justice.—Sir, you have heard, I fear, the little hope she gives; yet she loves, let that secure you.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Will you take my opinion of your Sister hereafter? This I He appears very sad and pensive. foresaw.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Something I will do, pray, let me serve her in some disguise, till she be freed from this place while I have an interest here.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: If I can, I'll perswade her to escape this night.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I would I had spoke with her, I would fain say something to her before I dye.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Dye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes dye, Facertes, now when I would fainest live; for why should I linger here when that which makes her excellent must render me miserable? for had she forgiven me, I could not have forgiven her; for she has justice, and I despair; farewell Facertes, I'll meet thee at the Galley.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Pray stay, Sir, you shall speak with her, and it may be she cannot find that strength against you.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: If you'll gain me the liberty of speaking with her, I shall gladly do it; and then what I will do shall ask no long time to consider.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, follow me.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I dare not press in there; I that have forced a passage through the world dare not enter there where love onely has the guard.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. VII.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: THey are now there; she is false, and you abus'd; she threatned me with wounds, unless I would obey her, and invite him to her bed, and the slave would scarce be won to come.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: But has she given the slave to him that I presented to her to day?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: She has given him all, and to lay the greater scorn upon you, to your enemy, she is one who loves the slave, and wants the common excuse of being woo'd.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Was this the reason she commanded me not to pursue my revenge? Fool, it shall now fall on you both.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: You must be speedy then; for this night they are gone, and the garden is the appointed place to receive the slave in; but if you'l obey my counsel, they shall find their graves there; and then the old woman will laugh at the young Rascals.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: But how shall I come to this opportunity of revenge?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Go arm your self, and take such to your assistance, whose
faith you have tryed, and bring'em in the evening to our garden, where I'll place you so, that you shall have a full view of them, and take your revenge safely.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: The Moon will assist us, for she shines early this night.—This in earnest. He offers her money.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Sir, I expect no money, I have said, I love you.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: O, excuse me till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir,—How all these young things are subject to oversee a woman when she is stricken a little in years! and this Fool too, whom I chuse, because I thought all had been alike to fools, and yet see how hardly he is drawn on; as I live, but that there is one young man that I love, I would make him kill'em both, and take the wench; Ah! farewell the memory of my dear Britain, Gorgianus; well did he deserve to be their Patron, he never refus'd and old woman, but they knew his virtue, and while he was young call'd him home. O happy Island, that has one young man in it that will be charitable to the old woman: Every one strives to feed the young till their bellies burst again, while we praise and beg, and can scarce get'em to sell us their ware.—How now, what have we here? oh is it you? I'll retire.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: If thou hast not lost all thine honour, By the memory of thy Fathers ashes, By that chaste Mother, whose memory thou so oft hast worshipped, give me leave to retreat to my strength, and while I have power preserve my honour, lest there be none left in our family, for thou hast thrown off thine, as if it had been a burthen to thee.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Dare you not hear him speak? if you have no Argument to deny what he said, why do you accuse me of weakness, when I was conquered?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I dare not longer hear him speak? for all the weakness that our sex or nature is subject to plead against me, and I have only honour to defend me; yet I can give you powerful Reasons that can destroy all his hopes.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: No, no, give 'em him when you see him.

div.stage: [Exit Facertes, and pulls to the door.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: 'Tis just you fly me, 'tis just you scorn me, and here I stand mine own judge, my own accuser and executioner too, if you frown, and bid me strike.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Sir, you mistake me, if you think I scorn you; there are other ways, and just ones, to be revenged without a fault.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Facertes, you do not covet a revenge more then I thirst to give it; and now I know what you desire, with wings I'll haste to serve you.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: You cannot, her fruits are seldom sweet, unless we pluck them our selves.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Let me beg you will not pay such a rate as your innocence for it, can you not forgive? Is there nothing can expiate
what my fate was only guilty in? for I was never faulty to you.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Nothing; my honour tells me I must not find a peace,—But my heart tells me I belie it.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Oh, do not frown; can you not be just but you must be angry too? The Judge that speaks the Malefactors fate, and tells him to morrow thou shalt dye, he do's it because it is just, not that he is pleas'd with the wretches misery. Oh, be you but so merciful; let my doom come but as a necessity from you, and not appear to affect my miseries.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Brother Facertes, what shall I say? Cicilia, be thy self, or thou hast lost the glory of thy revenge.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No, divinest, do not wrong me so, as to think I plead for life; 'tis for your pity onely that I beg; do not you destroy me, command some one that the act but addes to his guilt; stain not with blood that innocence, nor with cruelty punish cruelty.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: No, Sir, I know your friend has said enough to secure you I cannot be cruel; but since such a sullen fate attends me that my passion will rob me of the revenge I hop'd to have had on you, I'll take it on my self; and if thou lovest through my own wounds, strike thy false heart which I see, yet have no power to punish.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: False? oh, do not say so, any thing, but false.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Did'st thou not plead thus, till thy Arguments prevail'd with my Brother, that Brother under whose Sword thou fel ••• , and found'st protection, though his enemy? did'st thou not vow there he should not be led in triumph, who else would not have lived? for he defended himself only to let thy pride see thou could'st not overcome him; and when he had taught thee with his sword that he could conquer, he yielded to let thee see he durst dye.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Dare you be judg'd by that Brother?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Yes, when he is himself; but these injuries are silent, when I call to mind that barbarous rage that did not spare the aged snow of my honoured Father. What glory could his death add to your conquest, whose heart had not blood enough to stain the sacrilegious weapon.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, for these misfortunes which call me their head, I plead the duty I owed a Father, whose Battel I fought; and it became me to obey mine, as it do's you to mourn yours.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Then, to these add the vanity of this journey, promising your self a victory over our hearts too; and because your sword is forbid in this war, alone you undertook the journey; as if Virgilius name were enough to slave the world.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Madam, witness Facertes, how full of despairs I obeyed my fate, and your misfortunes will quit me of vanity; for when they had set a rate upon your beauty, when there was a price made for the excellent Cicilia, yet then I durst not hope a purchase. Vain, false and cruel! think me any thing but such a monster.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p:
Oh Brother! cruel Brother! Sir, if I have injur'd you, I shall teach you to forgive by forgiving greater faults: my faith,
and my faith, alas, that can neither advantage me, nor prejudice Virgilius.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Do not say so; 'tis the saving balm; 'tis mercy it self; and your faith of me must save me here, as mine hereafter; Oh, Divinest, stop not your mercy, but let it fall here; your eyes are full of pity; let that precious dew drop upon my thirsty heart, and save me, ere despair hath licked all my life thence; Turn not away, but look upon me as I appear in repentance, in the whiteness of my He kneels. tears, in their Innocency, in my Souls Love to Cicilia, strewed upon the Earth in submission. Behold me, and view me, not as I stand stained with thy miseries, but speak to me, and speak mercy, Mercy whose figure thy fair self wears, and adorns; O let her softness guide thy tongue, and let my Souls bleeding sadness make thy fathers wounds dumb.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Oh, ye gods, why did not ye make him Innocent? pray Sir, Why do you kneel?

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: For mercy, is there no mercy? your tears should be He rises. friendly; can you weep when you are Angry?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: No, Sir, my tears have Prophetique misery, and so much weakness in them, they deserve your pity.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, do not call it weakness, This is Charity, and her Alms yields a double benefit, and adorns as well as saves; Oh, my fate, would you had made me any thing that's most scorn'd, rather then an Enemy here.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: That had been too great a Blessing; for kno • Sir, you do not, more then I, wish your Innocence, or with sadder thoughts mourn your guilt.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: She must not see this Passion; Sir, pray let your love give way a little to Our safety; Paulina is coming, and 'twill be dangerous, by the discovery of yours, to put her Love to a despair; Sister, I hope your Reason has found a way to be reconcil'd to this Prince, whose misfortunes I know cannot deserve your hate; when your Justice guides; pray let her not see you here.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I can forgive him, and you; But I can ne're forgive my self; and something I'le do shall save my honour.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, put off this sadness, and sollicite Paulina to deliver her this Night; is she as unsensible of your Love as she appear'd to be?

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: She is all honour, all her self; All thy Sister, and I happy onely to be more miserable.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Pray retire, before Paulina comes.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: This way we shall meet her, courage Sir; After Parly Womans wars give Quarter still, and she cannot long be cruel.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: ARe you all provided?

sp.speaker: Barv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, how many are they?

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Three is the most; give me a Pistol, 'tis about the time she appointed, stay here, and whistle, if she comes; I'le look out.

sp.speaker: 1. Brav.
sp.p: This wench has every day a Quarrel; I kil'd two for her, the last Olympick.

sp.speaker: 2. Brav.
sp.p: Marry, the gods send her many Quarrels, peace Brings us no harvest; Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: The Moon is up, and he not come. They are upon departure; This Coward will fail me, and they will escape, and the Rascal will scorn me to death.

sp.speaker: 1. Brav.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: 'Tis I, whose that? the Prince?

sp.speaker: 1. Brav.
sp.p: No, Madam, but one of his Creatures.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Who's that? Ennius? why, where have you been many a day?

sp.speaker: 1. Brav.
sp.p: Faith, I durst not be seen till last night.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: You promis'd me a visit once, but you broke your word.

sp.speaker: 1. Brav.
sp.p: Lets retire, and call my Lord; I'Ie pay it now.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Follow me then, is my Lord this way?

sp.speaker: 1. Brav.
sp.p: Yes, let me guide you.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Who's that passed by?

sp.speaker: 2. Brav.
sp.p: It's the old Woman, that serves Paulina.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: O, are you ready, Sir, you have stayed the utmost time; she expects him with longing thoughts, they are all provided, and a Gally lies ready at the Mole, to convey them away; but if your hearts be true, we will stay their Journey.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: We are all ready, and resolute.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Follow me then, I'le see you plac'd where they must pass by.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Lead the way.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: WHat return to make you, for this good Act, I know not; But I shall ever admire you for daring (in so wicked a Place) to be so singly good.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p:
I, that durst be wicked, ought not to dispute now; but with shame to look upon my faults, and offer this, as my first sacrifice,
to witness I repent; and may my wishes prove fortunate, and make you happy in that Love that makes me miserable.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: You cannot be so miserable as I,—That must love my Aside. Enemy.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Madam, are you ready, they stay at the Garden gate, shall I let them in?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and see the gates shut that lead to the street.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: All is safe, pray make haste.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Wee'le meet you, call at my window.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. X.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: THis Moon is friendly, come, pray let not this cloudy sadness hang upon our Joys; you see she consented to put her self into your protection; her tears too are your warrant, for all Womens storms are past when those showers fall.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: I do not now grieve for fear she should be angry, but that I am so unlucky as to deserve it; and my Friends can witness my heart never sinned against her, yet something lies heavy upon it I cannot remove; for my fears tell me shee'l take some Revenge upon her self; for you saw it was her Passion, not her reason, that forgave me.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I know her Religion will protect her against her self, and she has too much honour, to wish health, and put poyson in the Cup; and though she threatned revenge, yet she scorns to take it when she is reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Oh, she is too Excellent to be false; Peace. Whose there?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Is the Galley ready, they Expect you.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: All's ready, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Follow me.

sp.speaker: Bragad. within.
sp.p: Stand close, I hear 'em come.

div.stage: Enter Virgil. Facertes, and Baud again.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Stay here, while I return, with the Key.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: This is the Garden. Bragadine s ••• s, Virgil puts his hand to his eye, with a bloody s • unge and the ble • d runs down. Facertes draws his sword, and takes him in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Oh! This may be just: but whether it be fair, or no, Heaven, thou see'st.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: How do you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Why well, Facertes; The Bullet but glanced.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Oh my sister, If thou hast a hand in this Treachery, may Plagues suddain and lasting find and sink thee with despairs, when mercy flies thee as thou hast done thy honour; nor shall all Virgil. is still in Facertes Arms. the tyes of love, or nature, prove thy guard, nor the mercies due to thy weeping penitence; No, thy sex shall not protect thee from the Justice of my swoln rage, which with sword, and words (that wound more) shall afflict thee.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Why dost thou rage and curse her, still mistaking that excellent Maid? Upon my Soul, she has no hand in't, she is too full of Honour, to take so base a way to her Revenge, or seek by Treachery a life that's onely worn to serve her; and when she frownes, may command me put it off.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Draw your sword then, and take my counsel, if your strength fail not, and fall, as if their malice had been more prosperous, He speaks softly to him. perchance the Villain, Author of this deed, lurks here about, and expects such a sign ere he dare discover himself.—Pray, Sir, Aloud. let me bear you home.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No, Facertes, let me die here. Virgilius draws his sword and lies down.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Unfortunate Youth, Murther, Villaines, where are you, you accursed Actors of this black deed? do you hide already Cowards? dare you not look on your Act? Cicilia and Paulina above.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: It was my Brothers voice that cry'd Murther.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I heard a Pistoll, where's Olympia?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Heark, there's some body comes.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Villaines, dare you not yet appear?

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Yes, fool, we dare, and laugh upon your miseries.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Yes, an old Woman will laugh; fool, thou had'st better have destroy'd thy Mother, then with scorn have awaked my Malice, now where is all your young wits? am not I prov'd a Mother of your Joyes? fool, I am reveng'd now.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What cry was that?

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: How now, what ailes you? Virgilius as he lies, runs his sword into the Baud, and kills her▪ she squeckes

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Oh me, oh me, I am dead.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Then, though our miseries be great, they are not so ill as I fear'd; what moved thee, Villain, to this base Act?

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Revenge, fool; thought'st thou, I could forgive a wound, and such an Injury as to have her I call mine possess'd by another?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Villain, thou shalt dearly pay for this base Act; Rise, Sir, Virgilius rises, and kills one of the Bravoes. the Truth is now at large discovered.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Ha, alive?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Yes, and I hope shall find so much Mercy as to punish thy Treachery.
They fight.
Virgilius and Bragadine. Facertes and Ennius.
They are all wounded, Bragad. faints and falls.
Kills him.
Facertes and Ennius struggle on the ground, Facertes kills him.
Dies.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Draw, Ennius, we have yet as many swords as they.

sp.speaker: Ennius.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, and as good hearts.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Traitor, thou want'st the cause.

sp.speaker: Cicilia above.
sp.p: It is they, they are set upon, I hear their swords too; let's haste, our presence may bring some aid; for Heavens sake, let us not look on and see them murthered.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Hold, as thou hast Mercy, hold; and as thou hast faults, shew Mercy.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, in this Justice, for Justice is ever merciful.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: There, Villain, There's thy treacheries first reward; thou art going for thy last.

div.stage: Enter Cicilia and Paulina; whilst they are fighting upon the ground, Cicilia runs to Facertes.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Ha! upon the ground, Facertes, what accident is this?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Where's the Prince?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Here, how fares Facertes?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Well, onely a little scratch'd.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you believe I had no hand in this Treachery.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No Madam, we know the unworthy cause.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: All our Joyes (within this minute) had a cloud on them; and I confess, I was afraid it had hid my Sisters faults, whilst I fear'd a mistake of Justice had betray'd thee to a Murther; yet then in his wounds the Prince was himself, and collected; I chid my mistrust; see, he bleeds still, do's not that expiate? This is twice he has shed it in sacrificing to thy liberty; and now to be angry is wilfull and humor, not honour.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Do you command, Cicilia shall obey; for I confess, the Prince is Master of that honour I but talked of; will you mediate a pardon for the Injuries my Passion threw upon him? and I shall joy to find I was mistaken.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: O Madam, do not speak of pardon, for your Innocence knows not the way to that Injury I could not forgive; But I will not talk; for I should hate my self, if I had words to express this Joy.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Ha! The Prince slain, and Olympia dead? as you love your safety haste hence; he whom your Justice has found is the Vice-Roy's Son, and its present death if you be taken.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: No distraction; The Galley is ready, and waits us at the Mole, thither we'll immediately; Sister, dare you yet put your self into the Princes Protection?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Yes, but not now; when I am free I will; and as I refus'd at first, because it was early, so now, 'cause it is forced, and looks like giving upon the Death-bed; and I would be loath to become the Princes Legacy.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I beseech you, let not a nicity interrupt my Joyes; but trust me with your protection, till I have made good my vowes to your Brother, whose Joyes my Affairs have deferr'd: But when you see him possessed of his Country, then I'll kneel for a Blessing in the fair Cicilia; dare you bid me hope?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: I promise to do what honour shall warrant 〈…〉 and when these wounds are heal'd, I shall not call it weakness that makes me yield to my passion.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: This Cloud is blown over by Fate; and now I'll smile and prophecy, through all our wounds and tears, a joyfull issue.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: We'll for Sicily first, the Vice-Roy being dead they dare not refuse my Authority; besides, if they do, the Army is mine, and that shall secure Facertes. Madam, what Commands have you to enjoyn me, that I may return this favour?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: When you appear'd a private Man and compass'd with dangers you had a power here, which now is turn'd to duty; and I beg a protection in your company, for the Prince was known to have an Interest here; and to be found dead in my Garden will bring a certain ruine upon me; For that I am Innocent will be no guard, but I shall fall now to expiate my other faults; and I confess, I would fain live now, for I am certain I repent, and shall ever sacrifice to the Prince Virgilius as my good Genius.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Sure we shall not deny you a safety, to whom we owe all ours.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: No Complement, but this way through the Garden to the Galley, the wind is somewhat high.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: The Clouds are black, we'll keep under the shore, that if need be, we may put in upon the Coast of Calabria.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Not I, as I live.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Let me beg that Olive branch sign of Peace; and witness He refuses to lead his S ster. all, I joy more to be thus bound, then to have conquer'd Sicily.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: THe Captain has refused to give me the freedom of her I Love, but if the Lieutenant keep his word, I shall make him repent it at as sad a rate as I bear my misery; 'tis not Love, sure, that afflicts my Heart, for I have heard 'em say, That it is a soft and gentle Passion, which strokes and courts the Mind, and his Cilius lies down. service perfect freedom, for Love is both the Famine and the Food, none of these chains afflicts them; I have seen Women and Boyes play with this Power: 'Tis the sport of Virgins, and yet their Hearts last Ages; Nay, they can be false too, and yet not lose one Grace, nor one Beautyfalls; Even the perjur'd Lovers weare their quiet Minds and fair Faces still, whil'st I pine and wither under these two dayes misery. I cannot eat nor sleep since I saw her, and my frinds are irksome to me, I love loanness, and hunt Corners, and prize a thought of being her slave, more then a Conquest over the world; Yet I stammer still, and cannot speak sence when my griefs would tell her, the story of what I ail. I have lost my Courage too of late; for, by all our Gods, I start and tremble when I see her; Nay, I am a Dog if I do not weep when I behold her; no Boy at School has his tears readier then I, I could weep like froward Children. This makes me mad, to find my self abandoned by all the Gods, whose ends I cannot guess, nor why they send me this new way to misery.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p:
How, Sir, upon the ground? up, Sir, the Souldiers are prepared, and expect your presence only to finish the work; The slaves too are loose and privately arm'd; and when he is once aboard, give but the sign, and be Master both of him and her.—Fie, Sir,
what means this dejection? up, for shame.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: See Lieutenant, I am grown the obedient'st thing that He helps him up. ever sigh'd himself away; O Lieutenant, kind old Friend, if we miscarry in this design, I am lost for ever; for I am become the wretched'st thing thy heart can fancy.—Prithee pray.— He leans upon him.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Bondue, pray? you have found your Man indeed.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: The Angry Gods to send Men and bold wounds, not cowardly thoughts and Women when they will, call Cilius to the Earth again.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Death! what ayle you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Oh Friend! this trouble of my Mind is sent like some new disease to scourge thy Friend, and act what sword and sickness could not do; and my despair will throw me upon some horrid Crime, against which 'tis in vain to oppose or Armes or Virtue; The Tyrant-Boy Lords it o're my Heart, and now he has wounded me will make me kiss the Dart.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Oh! is this it you complain of? Let me know Man or boy that dares wrong you; By this hilt, I will send him on a cold Errand.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Thy threats are vain, for my griefs are a disease I never felt before; The remedy too is hid from Gods and Men, the Maid, the lovely Maid thou gav'st me.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: A pox on her, the Wench, is she the cause? was she not sound, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Sound!

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: I, sound, by this hand for all that I know she was; I am a Dog if I touched her; and but for a kiss or two you had her as pure as I found her.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Peace, Beast.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: By this Light, Sir, I am in earnest, and unless 'twere Crab had a touch,—for no body else was alone with her, 'tis that old Rogue has spoild her.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Villain, Slave.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Why, in passion, Sir? you are not the first; why this, what a pox, a Clap is no such dishonour to a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Peace, wretch.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: He is modest; a Plague upon her for a dissembling prating Whore: By this hand I would ha' ventur'd my life she had been sound.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Dog, dost thou know her whom thou thus profan'st? Strikehim.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Know her? mischiefs know her and the whole sex, they are nothing but dissimulation: why do you strike me? you beg of me to be your Baud, and are angry for a mischance, thank your self; you were never quiet till you had a bout with her.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: He will mistake me still.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Mistake you? 'Tis you mistake your self; can I help it if you have a Clap; if you will tell me what you ail, there are wayes and easie cures enough for such chances, without the sword; you have but one remedy for all diseases, that damn'd sword, you think, can cure all.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Fool, thou hast prophan'd a Maid with thy base thoughts purer then thy Prayers.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: I understand not your Raptures; if she has given you a touch, I'll help you to a Chirurgeon, and my self to another; if you'll be modest and lick your self whole you may.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: How natural 'tis for him to apprehend such dangers as he has found. Fool, thou hast mistaken me all this while, and would'st thou have been silent I had told thee; 'tis her Eyes that have wounded me, and my disease is Love, desperate Love; if I can judge of that strange Passions; for 'tis Love for her that dies for another; hast thou a remedy for such a wound in the Mind?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Love, is that your disease? I am glad 'tis no worse; by my troth, Sir, if you will starve with meat before you, I will bury you, but I will never pity you; Love and Marriage are the only two mischiefs that belong to the Sex which I have not had, and therefore can onely prescribe you Wine and Women for a remedy.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Prithee no more and if thou lov's • me, let thy kindness excuse my Passion, without making Mirth of my misery.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Now. cannot I be angry with him though I bleed; Sir, I would fain serve you if I knew how. Can you tell what 'tis your Love would have? what does the blind Child cry for, would he lie with the Wench? by this hand I will fetch her to you once more, if I thought that would cure your disease.

No more as you are a Souldier, by your Honour no more; your Honesty in other things excuses your Ignorance in this; no more I say. Alone I will find my remedy; and this sword, as I said before, has a Cure for all my miseries; for he that dares die may defie the worst of Fates.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, but he that dies for a Woman in Italy is but a small friend to the Sex and Lachrymae, and by my consent should be buried in a feather-bed.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Enter the Lieutenant, and Souldiers chain'd.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: WHat, are you all resolv'd?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, release us and we'll do it.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Or must I make an Oration to perswade you to this Geer?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No, Sir, we need no perswasions.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Methinks you should not, considering I humbly desire you not to be hang'd, and shall take it for an obligation, if you will throw away your cold water, and pledge me in Greek wine, and entreat your worships to quit these iron Jewels, and hard benches, for Gold-chains and pretty Wenches.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Sir, we hope you do not mean to abuse us, and shew us this heaven only in words.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: By this good day I am real, and you shall all be loose and arm'd; and when he comes aboard, put off speedily, and then discover your selves; if he resists, kill him, if not, only bind him; by these hilts, I have order to hang you every man, and mine own safety tells me I were best to do it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh! Lieutenant, noble Lieutenant, you know we have been honest Rogues to you always.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: All but my friend that would cut my throat the other day, because I would not give him my Wench.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Lieutenant, I was faulty, and you may leave being a Lyon, and take revenge upon a Dog; but you know you spoil a good fellows drinking when ever you hang me; and it may be, you'l not find one to bear my part in your Catches when I am gone; and then you'l wish you had not been so revengeful.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: No, you Rogues, you know I am of a most merciful nature, and that makes you so presumptuous; and to confirm you, I'll have all joyn hands, and you shall see what a miracle I'll work; so now, circle me about while I conjure up a spirit that shall tell me all your thoughts, and you mine.

div.stage: Here they make a ring about him and sing a Catch.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: TO Bacchus bow, to Bacchus sing, with wine and mirth let's conjure him.
By his Mothers eye
And his Fathers thigh
By her God brought delight.
And his too glorious sight,
By Juno's deceit,
And they sad retreat
Appear, appear, appear
Kind God in Bottles, here.
Lo I appear, lo I appear.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: To Bacchus bow, to Bacchus sing, with wine and mirth let's conjure him.
By Ariadne's wrongs,
And the false youth's harms,
By the rock in his breast.
That fled from the distrest
By the tempest in her mind
Which ceas't when thou wert kind.
By those beauties that he fled,
And the pleasures of her bed.
Appear, appear, appear
Kind God in Bottles here.
Drink and I will appear.
Drink deep and I am here.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: To Bacchus bow, to Bacchus sing,

l.hi: 'Tis wine and mirth that conjures him.
By this blood of the Vine,
Thus pour'd on thy shrine;
By this full glass
To the last kind lass,
'Twas a girle twice nine
That clasp'd like thy Vine.
By this and that appear, appear, appear
Kind and kinder God in Bottles here.
Lo I appear, one kind bottle more and I will dwell here.
Then thus again we will conjure him
Because he has propitious been.
Hence this glass, a poor and single sacrifice,
A Hecatomb in this bottle dies,
By the men that thou hast won,
And the women thou hast undone.
By the friendships thou hast made,
And the secrets thou hast betray'd.
By this cure of our sorrow,
Thus charm'd till to morrow.
Appear, appear, appear
Kind God in bottles here.
Lo I appear, lo I am here,
And there and there;
Lo, I am every where.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Is Bacchus a Devil, Lieutenant, that he obeys your charm? I thought he had been a God.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Faith, that is as he is used, and may be both; But I mean he shall play the Devil now; and therefore each man take into his hand one of these Familiars; and when he has sucked the secret from him, let him release the spirit into the Cellar again.

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.p: But what secret, Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Converse with that spirit, and he will instruct thee: whisper to him thus.—Hup, and thou shalt find liberty slip down thy He drinks, they all drink. throat.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Hast thou met him yet?

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.p: Not yet, but I believe he's hard by, for I met his baggage; I could be angry to think he should have so many fine Wenches and we none.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: He's in the right, anger and lust, liberty is hard by, I warrant They all drink again. They throw all the bottles in at a hole upon the Stage, and cry liberty, liberty. it; but she is in the last drop, and have at her; will you take my word hereafter?

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Yes, but good Lieutenant, call to the devil for one Bottle more, and let it be burnt sack.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: It is too late, yonder comes our chief, The brave Cilius.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Chief, Lieutenant? We have no Chief, Lieutenant, but liberty.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: How now, Lieutenant, what noise is this?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: We have been consulting, Sir, about this business; I, and my fellow Souldiers here,—I have ground the Rogues to such an edge they will cut iron; and being perswaded they are free, you may command them like Dogs.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Haste then to the Galley, I'll stay the Captain and his company till you are aboard; and honest friends when this is done, command your own and my power to serve you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long live Cilius, long live Cilius.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Thanks to all, did the storm last night do no mischief amongst the Gallies?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I had taken six when I lay down, and it did but rock me.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Pray lose no time, but haste aboard; for I must wait upon the Captain.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Fear not us; how now, who have we here?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Gentlemen, and my fellow Souldiers, I have an humble suit to you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What is't, what is't?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: That I may have leave to live.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Live? why not?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: You must ask my Lieutenant that, he knows the reason better then I; for he has a bill of my hand, to be dead to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Thou art a fool, here's nothing but liberty; and he that dares drink shall never dye.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Nay, I'll drink, so I may live.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Hum! Fellow Tullius, no covenants, no conditions for drinking while you live, drink freely.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Joyn hands, and sing aboard, there's liberty.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. III.
div.stage: Enter Cilius and Sophia, with some of those Romans were taken Prisoners with her.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: MAdam, be confident, for it shall not be in his power to wrong you, my self will be your guard.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, last night (but that I threatned, not to out-live his injury) he had forc'd me.

sp.speaker: 1 Roman.
sp.p: We appear'd upon her call, and with our cries made him suspect the noise might have given notice to the Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p:
Force you? he dares not do it, by our Laws he dies, or any that forces a Virgin after she is in our publick Treasury, which you are now; for your price, Madam, if you were sold, is to be divided; 'tis true, if he will marry you, that priviledge he has as Captain;
he pays our shares, and takes you, but from all those dangers, my life and honour to pawn, I'le secure you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: The gods, Sir, I hope, will reward this goodness, and joyn with you to protect our Innocence.

sp.speaker: 2. Roman.
sp.p: Will it be long, Sir, ere we go to the Galley?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, he is now coming with the rest of the Slaves; I beseech you be not sad, it looks prophetickly, and 'tis a kind of ill Omen; The Souldiers are all firm for you, I dare not stay; for to be seen with you might breed Suspition.—I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: 1. Roman.
sp.p: Be not dejected, Madam, you see by what strange means your stars have raised you a power among your Enemies. This gallant youth will not be so false as to deceive your trust; and once in Italy Sophia's name is guard enough.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir, had you nam'd your self, or Countrey, The fam'd Nigro had found no Enemies here; for we are all a part of that unfortunate Island, that are thus forc'd to live by spoil of them that have destroyed us; and I am sad to think of the misfortune of Our Princess, especially this last Accident, wherein the vertuous Cicilia suffer'd; But for those slaves whose falshood were the Authors of her Misery, This day the Dogs shall, upon the hook, find a Justice.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Sir, I have no joy now left; for I have seen all my Masters family ruin'd; and Our Countrey sold to slavery, yet if we make haste, we may again redeem the unfortunate Cicilia; for being sold at Naples, 'tis not likely they will so suddenly remove her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We are this morning bound thither, the Slaves Mart is held there to day.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What do I hear? Nigro nam'd, was not that he my Brother saved in the Siracusan battel?

sp.speaker: 1. Roman.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and that was he that saved the Prince Facertes in that battel where his Father fell.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And the Princess Cicilia was she that Prisoner that the slaves stole? Oh, my Facertes, then thy hopes and mine are sunk.

sp.speaker: 1. Roman.
sp.p: Have patience, Madam, lest you discover who you are; these new griefs of their lost Princess may bring a certain ruine upon us, should they know how near a relation you have to the cause.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: I am instructed Sir, what are they that stand bound? They appear'd busie be •• re.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Roman Prisoners, slaves for the Mart.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Though their Tyrannies have made them odious; yet when I see them miserable it finds a pity.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Are you ready, Sir, all stays; The wind is fair too.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did the storm do no harm, last night? it was very violent for the time.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Not much, the Gallies were well moored, onely the Lyon drove.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come Sir, We have now a double Occasion; and I hope we shall in Naples find our last hope; Cilius, bring off the Slaves, and follow.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p:
I shall follow, to your pain, Come Madam, now let
your prayers strengthen our designs; for where they side, the party cannot lose.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Enter Virgilius, Facertes, Cicilia, Paulina, after the storm.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: MAdam, the unfriendly winds have forced us to an unfrequented place, and brought new troubles; but I hope your vertue can arm against them.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I am so used; Sir, to misery, that this is a common chance, and here onely the Gods war with us.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Pray let me serve you, your charity deserves a greater care then this.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Madam, the unruliness of the weather made you lose the benefit of last nights sleep; pray repose here while we watch, lest some rude passengers interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I cannot sleep, Sir, I have too many cares, and waking thoughts upon me, Brother; how do's our Friend do?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: She will not rest neither, she seems to be less able to bear troubles then you; pray give Example, and try to sleep, lest sickness find you, and add a heavy accident to your other misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: If the Prince will sleep too, I will try to betray my Lies down, She, and Virgilius kneeling by her. thoughts; for truly I am weary.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Till you are safe I cannot; but I'le kneel by you; are you not afraid of me? for 'tis my fortune and cross fate that brings you all these troubles; and where I am you cannot be happy; say Divinest, am not I troublesome to you?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, do not make me blush, to say you are welcome; for I grieve more, that you are so unfortunate as to have a share in my miseries, then that I was unfortunate; for I have now no wish, but that the Prince Virgilius had no Interest in the cause.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: No more of sadness now; but pray try if you can take some rest.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: 'Tis not sadness now; there is a Joy in this grief; and when we are happy, 'tis a pleasure to recount our pass'd miseries.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: What noise is that? The Lieutenant and Souldiers singing the Catch.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: It draws nearer.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Some Bacchanale, by their Song,—whether tends this noise, turn back again, there's no way this way.

div.stage: Enter singing, first the Souldiers, then the Lieutenant, the Catch of, To Bacchus bow.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Sir, we have seen strange things, and therefore let us go.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: How now, my Friend, who would you speak with?

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: With none of you; pray turn, and take another Path.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Turn, no not we; and I advise you not to stop us, for we have a world of Sack about us, and our way lies this way.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Lieutenant, by these hilts, 'tis he that kil'd our Corporal, he that fought for the Slave at Naples.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Is it so? Look about, it may be, she is here too.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What do you stare at? He points to Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I look for a thing that troubles you; Oh, there it lies; come fellows, we'le help 'em to carry it.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Away, be gone, or I'le make thee curse the time thy erring feet strayed this way.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Draw, Mates, Sir, we dare fight; you shall not brave us He winds a Horn. at home, though you did at Naples.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: Draw, Facertes, these are the same Pirates we charg'd when thy fair Sister was sold at Naples.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Yes, yes, these are they, and we will sell your worships there. Lieutenant winds a Horn again.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Lose no time, for that Horn was a Call, and I fear some aid.

div.stage: They all fight, Virgilius wounds the Lieutenant, Facertes kills a Souldier. Enter the Captain, Virgilius charges him, he retires, and Virgilius follows him off the Stage. Enter Cilius and Souldiers, Facertes and he fight. They take Facertes, Cicilia, and Paulina Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Though courage be a vertue, and beauteous conquest courted amongst men, yet murther has no share in either; and those that be disarm'd cannot be call'd enemies, nor their death conquest; and if ever you knew what it was to want it, you'l find mercy, and hear me, a kneeling Virgin that never bowed to any (but the Gods) before, and save my Brother.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: And save thy Brother?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: If there be any thing that's dear to thee, by that I conjure thee; save him.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Fair one, I have already unfortunately struck against one who now commands my fate; and know, I do not use to war with miseries; or if I could, who durst destroy what your prayers protect? or what desperate fool hope a safety, when your prayers have call'd down his ruine?—Take his life, unbind him, and bind me, if you cannot forgive; for know, there is one in Beauty, Innocence and Miseries so like you, that I glory to serve you; for 'tis a kind of sacrifice to her; for whose dear sake had you interpos'd those eyes, you had divided us more then seas; and would I were able to say too that she were free as well as safe; and something, it may be, I shall do for that liberty too.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: May your Prayers, your Sword, nor your Love never find a stop, but such as addes glory to the conquest, for being thus good, thus merciful.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, I cannot talk.—Souldiers, carry these to the Captains Quarter, and with your lives protect them from all insolence; let them be apart with the Romans, and stay with them till I come. Your pardon, Madam, I must hence, lest this accident discover a Plot, whose good success may make me capable to serve you; if it miss, it brings a ruine where I must love, and cannot hope return. Sir, you that know so well how to deal wounds, I am certain will forgive them.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, I never hated the person of mine enemy, much less you that have proved a friend.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: I dare not stay; your pardon. Be careful of your charge; and do you hear, be speedy, and meet me at the Captains Quarter; my peace dwell for ever here.

div.stage: Enter Captain wounded, leaning on a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am paid, how the slave has notch'd me!

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: How do you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How do I? why thou seest I am spoil'd: a douzen of Surgeons will scarce repair me; how now, what are those?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Prisoners, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There's some comfort in that, come, bring 'em away, bring 'em away, set half a douzen of Surgeons to work.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Oh Facertes, I fear the Prince is lost.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: HA! gone, fool that I was, whither did my rage guide me? I have fought and conquer'd to my ruine, as rashly and unreasonably as beasts, forgetting the cause for which I fought; they are gone, which way shall I take? Love, either guide me to her rescue, or to my grave.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I am pay'd; what a case I am in—The Bottle is whole, He crys hup, and holds his breath. that's some comfort still; I live now by the Spirit of sack, for all my blood's gone.—H'as lam'd my drinking hand too: How shall I stop a Pipe? I leak apace, and reel as if I were drunk; how I stumble? dying is a king of being drunk; It grows night by my eyes; I shall faint ere I get to my Quarter. A pox take him that set me abroach, he has quite spoil'd my skin, a Tanner will not give a groat for it,—This is the first time that I remember He stumbles and falls. I ever fell when I was sober; if I die alone, I shall be as Melancholy, as a lame man in a ditch, Oh! for a Beer Glass of Sack, or Crab, and a Catch, to prepare for the Melancholy, and a cold grave.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: This was my Lieutenants plot, All the world is my Enemy; how they have hack'd me, it is a scurvy trade, this fighting it wears out ones cloaths, worse then drinking; I will hide me in this Wood till the storm is over; and if I get safe to Naples, Celia and I will live out my few days merrily, and spoil my Captains plot; I Tullius lies down in the Wood. will spend all, and die mine own heir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Sure I heard Tullius his voyce; who's there?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: I am pursu'd, yet if I can counterfeit dead well, I may live; My fear will betray me; O that I were valiant enough but to lie still; I never found the use of courage till now: Lord, how I shake!

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: 'Tis his voice; Tullius, Tullius, prithee stay a little.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: 'Tis my Lieutenant; if he should take this opportunity now, and kill me, and say the Enemy did it, and share with my Captain in all I have; Oh, the misery of Wealth! men can neither be happy with it, nor without it; I dare not look towards him, I'le creep backward, and run away.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: The ill-natur'd Rogue is gone, and left me; I shall bleed to death before any Friend finds me; Now the Rogue is reveng'd upon me for the frights I put him in to day.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p:
Hum! say you so, bleed to death—His wounds have heal'd mine—Now do I grow strong, and valiant—Lieutenant
He goes to the Lieutenant. how is't?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
