sp.p: Faith, quite spoil'd, I fear the Rogues have made lanes quite through me; prithee help me to my Quarter, for I am faint.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Has been something uncivil with your Breeches, I smell it,—How fell you out? did he refuse my Captains health? Tull. smells to him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: No, no, there was no wine in the business, yet there was a Wench, the other half of mans mischief; but 'tis no time now for to talk, for unless thou help'st me to a Surgeon, thou wilt find me a mortal Lieutenant.—Give me thy hand good Tullius, oh! what Tull. shakes him by the hand, and instead of helping him up lets him fall. hast thou done.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas! farewell, noble Lieutenant, We must all dye; there is a tall man, and a fair drinker, gone; I will say that for thee.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why Tullius, thou wilt not leave me in this misery? I have not fingers enough to stop the holes; get a Surgeon, or I shall dye.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: 'Tis sack, pure sack, and 'tis pity it should leak thus; but Tull. put his finger to the Lieu. side and smells. that I will not hinder our Captain the occasion of being your heir, when you die so conveniently now, just upon his going out.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: A pox o'this fooling, 'tis unseasonable; be but kind to me, and thou shalt be my heir.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: How! your heir? By this light, and 'tis well consider'd, now I think on't; I will be thy heir, or at least a careful steward for my Captain; let me see, this sword has a good guard, this hat and feather how sits it?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: What do'st thou mean?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: This Buff-coat will not be amiss neither.— He begins to strip him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Villain, unhand me.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you must part.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Dog.— Kicks him as he lies.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: And these Breeches too, and this Doublet, I'll wear them for your sake; nay, no resisting.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Slave, Villain.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: See how impatient you are, come, come, you are going to another world (as you say) quit the thoughts of these transitory things now, and prepare to dye finely like a fine gentleman, and a Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Hell take thee, slave.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: 'Tis more then ever I got by a Legacy before; by my faith, 'tis a fair Coat; a pox take'em that cut it thus: Now for the Breeches.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not murder me?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: No, no, only borrow your Breeches; for look, Sir, what need you such gay things as these now when you are going to lie alone in the dark?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Oh! misery of miseries!

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Ha, ha, this revenge is better then long life.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: O inhumane slave! A noise within.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: 'Tis vengeance, slave; I will make thee curse thy self.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Silence, my small friend, or else I have a Plaister of cold He draws his Dagger. iron, hight a Dagger; By this hilt, I will apply the point to your side, if you breathe one loud syllable more; marry, if you will, curse inwardly; 'twas my own case once, and I forgive it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Patience, oh patience.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: I, I, come when she will, you will have use of her; this noise draws this way, I must pluck him into the wood, and then I'll cut his throat; you had best bethink you of some odd prayer, for it must be so. He pulls him by the heels off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Murther, Villain, Dog.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Come, come along, Sir; why should you grudge to dye when I am to be your heir?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Oh misery, misery of miseries, is there no revenge?

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. VI.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: WHence grew this sudden Alarm?

sp.speaker: 1 Rom.
sp.p: I fear, from the discovery of the Plot; if it be so, we are lost for ever.

div.stage: Enter Captain and Nigro, after them Facertes, Cicilia and Paulina.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lead them in and bind 'em, and some one run for a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: What are these, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I know not; pray heaven they be worth the purchase: We have paid dear for 'em; prethee help me off.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Facertes! 'tis he, and women in his company; I will not suspect him she that is jealous; sets a cheap rate upon her self; for if he be worthy of such a pain as jealousie, he cannot be so faulty as to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I am amaz'd, 'tis the Princess Sophia.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p:
What miseries do I see, Madam, to add to mine own afflictions; I never thought I should have liv'd to see the day
wherein I should have grieved to have met the fair Sophia.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why are you afflicted to meet me now?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, my love begets my sorrows; for what shall I think? my thoughts are divided, to meet your Highness, where license sows, and sin reaps; here, where rage fetches her fire, and murther bathes his bloody hands; and unsensibly recounts in security the treacherous stabs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Say this guilt be here, must I be subject to the infection?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I do not think you are guilty, yet my fears tells me, where tir'd lust retires to pant, such beauties as adore the fair Sophia, must kindle fresh fires.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why do you wound me thus with your suspition, and rob me of the joy I had to see you? 'tis not kindly done to add such a pain to my misfortune; had you fall'n into the power of our sex, though sold to sin; like these, I could have dy'd sooner then have injur'd you so as to think you would-out live your honour; and when you are just to me, you will not believe I prize mine so little as to sell it for a sham'd life.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Oh! divinest, pardon my love, whose fears still apprehend the worst.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Madam, let the impatiency that begets this rudeness excuse it while I profess my self, by all ties, yours; for though, till now, a stranger to you; yet I am one that owes your civil mentions a life, which your mercy lent this unfortunate Brother.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Speak, Facertes, is this the Princess, Cicilia?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: This was; but what she is now the Gods only know. They embrace and weep.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, in love and miseries we are become one; and my whole stock of tears I would waste here, could that wash off my Countries crime, or remove the stain.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I have forgot my part of them; so new and so strange are the favours you and your gallant Brother have loaded us with, that his dangers now are all my fears.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: My Brother! where is he? have you seen him?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; and I fear he is at this instant hunting, with certain danger, our uncertain safety.

div.stage: Enter Nigro, Captain, and a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ha! the same Prisoners that were stole, and sold at Naples.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Upon my life, Sir, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: 'Tis, 'tis she, and the Prince Facertes too. Nig. kneels, and they embrace him.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: The honour'd Nigro?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Alive? oh ye Gods! This day is full of your hands; and all is like you (wonder.)

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Rise, why do you kneel? oh, lay that aged head here; where are we? what strange place is this the Sicilian Deity is run to hide her self in?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Though I do not know thy face; yet to Facertes name, here kneels a subject, and one of those your dead Father call'd faithful, my name Terresius.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes Terresius, Nigro, that with him from the same battle, when you fled with this gallant Prince, bore away the hopeful Lucius; we have run strange fortunes since; but I durst not tell him what he was, lest his fiery nature should have pull'd on a certain ruine.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: My Brother Lucius living?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and that, I hope, will expiate the fault my ignorance this day committed.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Where is he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I left him pursuing the victory, but I'll haste and tell him this news it will stay his rage, which else may pursue his own ruine upon his friends.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: For heavens sake haste, lest he and the Prince Virgilius meet; for either of their conquests brings my ruine.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Let me accompany you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I dare not, Sir, for yet the Souldiers know you not; and their mistake of duty to me may bring on a sad consequence.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: For heavens sake lose no time, but haste to prevent this danger.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll send an Officer, Sir, to guard you; and then with safety you may come but till then; I beseech you stir not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what blest chance brought my Brother to have the power to serve you.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Defer that story till a fitter time, and haste now to the saving of your Brother.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Pray lead the way, lest our ceremony hinder our charity.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: If you'l give me leave to command, I'll obey; you must not refuse me your hand; oh! that the Gods had made our Countries joyn thus in peace.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: THey cannot escape; I have fir'd their Galley, and mine lies loose, in wait for any that shall come to their aid. Miserable Virgilius! unfortunate that I am, preserved onely to a greater loss; this way a Souldier (whose dying words could only guide me) said they took; I'll hunt them to their den but I'll find the monsters.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. VIII.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p:
THe Galley fir'd, and the Lieutenant slain; Hell upon him, he has cross'd all my designs; Fate thou art Fate
still, but whither just or no thus to strike against the intentions of the honest, the Gods be Judge; All my hopes are sunk; that excellent Maid is lost too, and I shall appear guilty and treacherous to her; But if I find the cursed Incendiary, with his hatefull Blood I'll quench the flame: Take that path, if you find him, call.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Sir, this is he. As the Souldier goes o •• , he calls Virgilius.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: This, by description, should be him I seek.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What art thou, that walk'st with such confidence in these forbidden Woods? Know, thou hast kindled a fire nothing but thy Blood shall extinguish.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Unless thou wilt fall too, and make one in that ruine, I counsell thee immediately to deliver (without repetition) those whom thy treacherous odds have ravished hence.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I will not revile thee, because I mean to fight with thee; Yet I would gladly know whence thou art, that hopest with thy threats to wash off this glorious colour, and shake those fruits that Conquest gave a growth to here.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Rome claimes my Birth.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: So it do'es of him I hate more then the loath'd Issues of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What art thou, that dar'st avow such a hatred of a Roman to a Roman's face?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I am of Sicily, the unfortunate subject of your Rage.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: So is she I prefer equal with the Gods; yet her interest in the Nation shall not protect thee that art so base as to make spoil of thine own nest.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: You'll find words of no force here, and thou lookest as if thou would'st not yield upon intreaty.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Nor canst thou conquer me, when I fight in her cause, though thou tak'st the odds of his sword.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: His? he dares not strike, where he sees my sword drawn upon a single opposite.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: You will not deliver these Ladies then?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I'll give thee all my glory first; yet I know thou art the Author of all those miseries that shall succeed; for had'st not thou burnt my Galley, I had decreed their safety, but now thou hast sold them to perpetual slavery.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: The guilty never want excuses, but I shall punish both those falshoods.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Souldier, upon your life stir not a foot to my rescue, I scorn to live upon Charity.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I'll talk no longer, their freedomes or thy sword; for my vowes are writ in Heaven, never to sheath this sword till I found them or a Grave.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: One of them I'll guide you to, or miss my aime.—Fortune, They fight, and are both wounded. Cilius staggers. hast thou decreed that I shall blush to death? Loose where my Love and Countries Genius both strike? If thou bee'st a Deity save my Honour.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Will you yield, or try a farther Fate?
They fight, and in the close Vigilius takes bold of Cilius sword.
They struggle upon the ground, a noise within crying follow follow.
Virgil. and Cilius rise together and part.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, Roman, we may be overcome, but we scorn to yield.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Ask thy life, or thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, when thou canst give it, 'tis not worth asking.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Then 'tis not worth taking.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: I know not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Draw, and kill any thing that offers to rescue me; for when Cilius cannot stand alone in this cause, let him fall for ever.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I would thou had'st not deserv'd my sword.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Stand, he that advances a step as Friend or Enemy, till they have done, shall kill or die.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now, Sirrah? Cilius, if the name of Facertes or Cicilia have a power, you'll cease to be an Enemy there. They go to them.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Or if the brave Virgilius be satisfi'd with shedding of Scicilian Blood, he will now spare the lost Lucius, and reconcile himself They part 'em, they gaze upon one another. to that Brother Enemy.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Prince Lucius!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Virgilius, and there are coming those whose Interest in either will quickly clear this doubt.

div.stage: Enter Facertes, Cicilia, Sophia, Paulina, and Romans.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Sir, by the name of Brother; I conjure you to defer this hate till you have heard us speak.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: And if I have a Sisters interest it will disarm Virgilius.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Sister? what strange accident brought thee hither?—Madam, will you pardon that uncivil Joy that pass'd you to find To Cicilia. a Sister?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, if you'll help me find a friend to Virgilius, and a lost Brother to Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Terresius, unfold this Riddle, amazement yet with-holds my sword, and has almost bound my Reason; what means this shuffling of Facertes, Cicilia, Virgilius and Lucius together? Those names, and this dearness, what means it?

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Dare you trust me?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: The honour'd Nigro.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Or me, whose faith you have bought; and give us leave to reconcile this wonder?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Madam, I am all your slave, and when your hand deals it destruction shall fall on Cilius unresisted.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Dare you shew your breast? 'tis all I beg.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Yes, fair one, and every thought of it shall to you be visible.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Here, here, 'tis a thousand witnesses to prove the lost Lucius.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis so, and upon his knees Teresius begs his pardon for keeping this secret so long from you; But now it comes accompany'd with many blessings; see here your Brother, the Prince Facertes, and the Excellent Cicilia, whose Loves have been by Fate appointed to restore our Country to her long-lost liberty.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: And if Lucius finds a part of this Joy, let him with friendly armes embrace Virgilius, who is now a Brother, and ever a Friend.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Dare you from my hand take him?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: That I have been thus long silent, let the wonder you have begot plead for me; And, Sir, that we durst be Enemies should They embrace be no stop to that faith, which confirms we dare be friends.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Sir, your last act assures Virgilius, who cannot believe he is safe till you embrace him; for I know, such an Enemy as Prince Lucius reconcil'd will prove a conquering friend.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: The Gods make this friendship as lasting as 'tis strange.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Madam, doth this change bring no hope to Lucius? must he still be the despairing Cilius? dare you not yet tell me who you They embrace again. are?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Yes, my Name's Sophia.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Ha, the Princess Sophia?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Yes, Lucius: But why is my Brother sad? do's he mourn my Interest there?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, Sir, I neither mourn yours there, nor the Excellent Sophias here; but I am hunting out a way to bear my self like Lucius in this great day; your hand, Madam,—Here Facertes from Fate receive this Jewel, 'tis a Wealth I cannot hope to possess, but by being unworthy of it; and it shall be Lucius his glory to say, To keep his Fame, he gave that away.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Let no replyes defer the Joyes that attend this day.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: To the Temple then, while with healing sacrifice Virgilius loads the Altars.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I shall follow, if Lucius will lead the way. Thus blest, and thus embraced, more a God then they.
sp.l: Yet lest we leave our Enemies behind,
Let's know how these our Judges stand enclind.

div.p: THE Parsons Wedding, A COMEDY. The Scene LONDON.
WRITTEN AT Basil in Switzerland: BY THOMAS KILLIGREW.
DEDICATED TO THE LADY URSULA BARTU, WIDOW.
LONDON: Printed by J. M. for Henry Herringman, and are to be sold at his Shop at the sign of the Blew Anchor, in the lower Walk of the New-Exchange. 1663.

list.head: Dramatis Personae.
list.item: Mr Careless, A Gentleman, and a Wit.
Mr Wild, A Gentleman, Nephew to the Widow.
Mr Jolly, An Humerous Gentleman, and a Courtier.
Captain, A Leading Wit, full of Designs.
Parson, A Wit also, but over-reached by the Captain, and his Wanton.

row.cell: Two dull Suitors to the Lady Widow, and Mris Pleasant.

list.item: Lady Wild, A rich (and somewhat youthful) Widow.
Mris Pleasant, A Handsome young Gentlewoman, of a good Fortune.
Lady Love-all, An old Stallion Hunting Widow.
Mris Wanton, The Captains Livery Punk, Marryed to the Parson by Confederacy.

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter the Captain in Choler, and Wanton.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No more, I'le sooner be reconcil'd to want, or sickness, then that Rascal; A thing, that my Charity made sociable; one, that when I smil'd would fawn upon me, and wag his stearn, like starved Dogs; so nasty, the Company cried foh upon him; He stunk so of Poverty, Ale, and Bawdry. So poor and despicable, when I relieved him, he could not avow his calling, for want of a Cassock, but stood at Corners of Streets, and whisper'd Gentlemen in the Ear, as they pass'd, and so deliver'd his Wants like a Message which being done, the Rogue vanished, and would dive at Westminster like a Dabchick, and rise again at Temple-gate; The ingenuity of the Rascal, his Wit being snuft by want, burnt cleer then, and furnish'd him with a bawdy Jest or two, to take the Company; But now the Rogue shall find he has lost a Patron.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: As I live, if I had thought you would have been in such a fury, you should never have known it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Treacherous Rogue, he has always rayl'd against thee to me, as a danger his Friendship ought to give me warning of; and nightly cry'd, yet look back, and hunt not, with good Nature and the beauties of thy Youth, that false Woman; But hear thy Friend, that speaks from sad Experience.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Did he say this?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Yes, and swears ye are as unsatiate as the Sea, as Covetous,
and as ungrateful: that you have your Tempest too; and Calmes, more dangerous then it.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Was the slave so Eloquent in his malice?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, faith, and urg'd, you (for your part) were never particular, and seldom sound.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Not sound? Why, he offer'd to marry me, and swore he thought I was chast, I was so particular; and prov'd it, that consent was full marriage, by the first Institution, and those that love, and lie together, and tell, have fulfill'd all Ceremonies now.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did he offer to marry thee?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If ever then I deserv'd from thee, or if thou be'st deer to thy self, as thou hast any thing thou hop'st shall be safe or sound about thee, I conjure thee, take my Counsel; Marry him, to afflict him.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Marry him?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If I have any power I shall prevaile; thou know'st he has a fat Benefice, and leave me to plague him, till he give it me to be rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Will you not keep me then?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I keep thee? prithee, wilt thou keep me? I know not why men are such Fools to pay? We bring as much to the sport, as Women; Keep thee? I'de marry thee as soon; Why? that's Wedding sin; No, no keeping I, that you are not your own, is all that prefers you before Wives.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I hope this is not real.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Art thou such a stranger to my humor? Why I tell thee, I should hate thee if I could call thee mine, for I loath all Women within my knowledge, and 'tis six to four if I knew thy sign I'de come there no more; A strange Mistris makes every night a-new, and these are your pleasing sins; I had as live be good, as sin by course.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Then I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not so, if you'le be instructed, and let me pass like a stranger when you meet me.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: But have you these humors?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes faith; yet if you will observe them, though you Marry him, I may perchance be your Friend; But you must be sure to be coy; for to me the hunting is more pleasure then the Quarry.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: But if I observe this, will you be my Friend hereafter?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Firm as the day; Hark, I hear him; I knew he would The Parson calls within. follow me, I gave him a small touch that waken'd his guilt; Resolve to indear your self to him, which you may easily do, by taking his part when I have vex'd him; No dispute, Resolve it, or as I live here I disclaim thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: 'Tis well, something I'le do.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Open the door, I say, and let me in; your favorite and his Tythes, shall come no more here.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p:
Yes, but he shall; 'tis not you, nor your brac'd Drum, shall fright me hence, who can command the souls of men; I have read
Divine Seneca; thou know'st nothing but the earthly part, and canst cry to that, Faces about.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thou read Seneca? thou steal his Cover, to clothe thee, naked and wicked, That for money wouldst sell thy share of the Twelve, and art allow'd by all that know thee, fitter to have been Judas, then Judas was for his treachery.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Rail, do Rail, my illiterate Captain, that can only abuse by memory; and should I live thou couldst read my Sentence, I should never die.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No ingrateful, live till I destroy thee; and thankless Wretch, Did all my care of thee deserve nothing but thy malice, and treacherous speaking darkly still? with thy fine, No, not he, when any malicious discourse was made of mee, and by thy false faint, No, Faith; Confess, in thy denials, whilst thy smiling Excuses stood a greater and more dangerous Evidence against me, then my Enemies Affidavits could have done.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I'le lie for never a lean Souldier of you all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have, for thee, slave, when I have been wondred at for keeping Company with such a face; But they were such as know thee not; all which thy looks deceiv'd, as they did me; They are so simple they'd Couzen a Jury, and a Judge that had Wit would swear thou ly'dst, shouldst thou confess what I know to be true, and award Bedlam for thee; 'tis so strange and so new a thing, to find so much Rogue lodge at the sign of the Fool.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Leave this injurious language, or I'le lay off my Cassock, for nothing shall priviledge your Braggers tongue, to abuse me, a Gentleman, and a Souldier ancienter then thy self.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, thou wer't so; and now I think on't, I'le recount the Cause, which, it may be, thou hast forgot, through the variety of sins; It was a Hue and Cry that follow'd thee a Scholar, and found thee a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Thou ly'st; thou, and scandal have but one tongue, hers dwells with thy Cowards teeth.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh! do you rage? nay, I'le put the cause in Print too, I am but a skirvy Poet, yet I'le make a Ballad shall tell how like a faithful disciple you follow'd your poor Whore, till her Martyrdom in the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I'le be reveng'd for this scandal.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then shall succeed, thy flight from the University, disguis'd into Captain only the outside was worse Buff, and the inside more Atheist, then they furnish'd with an Insolent Faith, uncharitable heart, envious, as old Women, cruel and bloody as Cowards; thus arm'd at all points, thou went'st out, Threatning God, and trembling at men.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I'le be reveng'd, thou poor man of War, I'le be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: And why so bitter? whose house is this? who dares tell this story?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Why sweet? hath he not treacherously broke into our Cabinet, and would have stol'n thee thence? By these hilts, I'le
hang him; and then I can conclude my Ballad with, Take warning all Christian People by the same: I will, you lean Slave; I'le prosecute thee, till thou art fain to hide in a Servitors gown again, and live upon Crums with the Robin Red-breasts that haunt the Hall, your old Mess-Mates; Do you snarle? I'le do't, I will, and put thee to fight with the Dogs for the Bones that but smell of meat; those that your hungry Students have polish'd with their teeth.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: If you do this, good Captain, Lieutenant, and Company (for all your Command, I think, is within your reach) I say, if you dare do this, I shall sing a song of one that bad stand, and made a Carrier pay a dear Rent for a little ground, upon his Majesties high-way.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now, Mistress Wanton? What's this? What's this?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: This? 'Tis matter for a Jury, I'le sweare, and positively, I'le hang thee, I'le do't, by this hand, let me alone to swear the Jury out of doubt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But you are in Jest, Mistris Wanton, and will confess (I hope) this is no truth.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes Sir, as great a truth, as that you are in your unpay'd-for Scarlet; Fool! didst think, I'de quit such a Friend, and his stay'd fortune, to rely upon thy dead pay, and hopes of a second Covenant?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: His fortune? what is'st? Th'Advowson of Tybourn Deanry?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No, nor Rents brought in by long staff-speeches, that asks Alms with frowns, till thy looks and speech have laid violent hands upon mens Charity.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Let him alone, I'le warrant, hee'l never be indicted for drawing any thing but his tongue, against a man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Dear Mrs Wanton, you have won my heart, and I shall live to dote upon you for abusing this impetuous Captain; will you listen to my old suit? will you marry me, and vex him? say, dare you do't, without more dispute?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Twas a good Question; she that dares marry thee dares do any thing; she may as safely lie with the great Bell upon her, and his Clapper is less dangerous then thine.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Why, I pray?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What a miserable condition wilt thou come to? his wife cannot be an honest Woman; and if thou should'st turn honest, would it not vex thee to be chaste and Paxat, a Saint without a Nose? what Kalender will admit thee, by an incurable slave that's made of Rogues flesh, consider that.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Why, that's something yet; Thou hast nothing but a few scars, and a little old Fame to trust to, and that scarce thatches your head.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay then I see thou'rt base, and this Plot (not Accident,) and now I'doe not grudge him thee; go together, 'tis pity to part you, Whore and Parson, as consonant.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: As Whore and Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Take her, I'll warrant her a breeder, I'll prophecy she shall lie with thy whole Congregation, and bring an Heir to thy Parish, one that thou maist enclose the Common by his Title, and recover it by Common Law.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: That's more then thy dear Dam could do for thee, thou Son of a thousand Fathers, all poor Souldiers, Rogues, that ought mischiefs, no Midwives for their Birth; But I cry thee Mercy, my Patron has an Estate of old Iron by his side, with the Farm of old Ladies he scrapes a dirty living from.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: He earn from an old Lady? hang him, he's only wicked in his desires; and for Adultery he cannot be condemn'd, though he should have the vanity to betray himself; God forgive me for belying him so often as I have done; the weak-chin'd slave hir'd me once to say, I was with Child by him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This is pretty, Farewell; and may the next Pig thou farrow'st have a promising face, without the Dads fool or Gallows in't, that all may swear, at first sight, That's a Bastard; and it shall go hard but I'll have it call'd mine; I have the way, 'tis but praising thee, and swearing thou art honest before I am askt: You taught me the trick.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Next Levy I'll preach against thee, and tell them what a piece you are; your Drum and borrowed scarf shall not prevail, nor shall you win with Charmes half-ell-long, (hight ferret Ribband) the youth of our Parish, as you have done.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, lose no time, prithee study and learn to preach, and leave railing against the Surplice, now thou hast preach'd thy self into Linen; Adieu, Abigal, Adieu, Heir apparent to Sir Oliver Marre-text; To Church, go, I'll send a Beadle shall sing your Epithalamium.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Adieu, my Captain of a tame band, I'll tell your old Lady how you abused her breath, and swore you earn'd your money harder then those that dig in the Mines for't. Exit Captain. A fart, fill thy sail, Captain of a Gally Foyst. He's gone, come sweet, let's to Church immediatly, that I may go and take my Revenge; I'll make him wear thin Breeches.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: But if you should be such a Man as he sayes you are, what would my Friends say, when they hear I have cast my self away?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p:
He sayes? Hang him, lean, mercenary, provant Rogue; I knew his beginning when he made the stocks lowsie, and swarm'd so with vermin we were afraid he would have brought that Curse upon the County; He sayes? but what's matter what he sayes? a Rogue, by Sire and Damm; his Father was a broad fat Pedler, a what do you lack, Sir, that haunted good houses, and stole more then he bought; His Damm was a Gypsie, a pilfering canting Sibyll in her youth, and she suffered in her old age for a Witch; Poor Stromwell, the Rogue was a perpetual Burthen to her, she carried him longer at her back then in her belly; he dwelt there, till she lost him one night in the great Frost upon our Common, and there he was found in the morning candid in Ice: a pox of
their Charity that thaw'd him, you might smell a Rogue then in the bud, he is now run away from his Wise.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: His Wife?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, his Wife; Why, do you not know he's married according to the Rogues Liturgy? a Left-handed Bridegroom; I saw him take the Ring from a Tinkers Dowager.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Is this possible?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, most possible, and you shall see how I'll be reveng'd on him; I will immediatly go seek the Ordinance against Reformadoes.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: What Ordinance?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Why, they do so swarm about the Town, and are so destructive to Trade and all Civil Government, that the State has declared, No person shall keep above two Colonels and four Captains, (of what Trade soever) in his Family; For now the War is done, Broken breech, Wood-monger, Rag-man, Butcher, and Link-boy, (Comrades that made up the ragged Regiment in this holy War) think to return and be admitted to serve out their times again.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Your Ordinance will not touch the Captain, for he is a known Souldier.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: He a Captain? an Apochryphal Modern one, that went Convoy once to Brainford with those Troops that conducted the Contribution-Puddings in the late holy War, when the City ran mad after their Russet Levites, Apron-Rogues, with horn hands; Hang him, he's but the sign of a Souldier; and I hope to see him hang'd for that Commission, when the King comes to his Place again.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: You abuse him, now he's gone; But,—

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Why? dost thou think I fear him? No Wench, I know him too well for a Cowardly slave, that dares as soon eat his Fox, as draw it in earnest; the slave's noted to make a Conscience of nothing but fighting.

sp.speaker: Vant.
sp.p: Well, if you be not a good Man, and a kind Husband—

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Thou know'st the Proverb, as happy as the Parsons Wife, during her Husbands life.

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Enter Mistress Pleasant, Widow Wild her Aunt, and Secret, her Woman, above in the Musick Room, as dressing her, A Glass, a Table, and she in her night cloathes.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: SEcret, give me the Glass, and see who knocks.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Niece, what, shut the Door? as I live this Musick was meant to you, I know my Nephews voice.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, but you think his friends has more Musick in't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No Faith, I can laugh with him, or so, but he comes no nearer then my lace.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You do well to keep your smock betwixt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Faith, Wench, so wilt thou and thou beest wise, from him and all of them, and be rul'd by me, we'll abuse all the Sex, till they put a true value upon us.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: But dare you forbid the travel'd Gentlemen, and abuse them and your servant, and swear, with me, not to marry in a twelve moneth, though a Lord bait the hook, and hang out the sign of a Court Cupid, whipt by a Country Widow; then I believe we may have mirth cheaper then at the price of our selves, and some sport with the wits that went to lose themselves in France.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, no dissembling, lest I tell your servant, when he returns, how much you're taken with the last new fashion.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis almost Noon, will you not dress your self to day?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: She speaks as if we were Boarders; Prethee, Wench, is not the dinner our own, sure my Cook shall lay by my own Roast till my stomack be up.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: But there may be Company, and they will say, we take too long time to trim. Secret. Give me the flowers my servant sent me, he sware 'twas the first the Wench made of the kind.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But when he shall hear you had Musick sent you to day, 'twill make him appear in his old cloathes.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Marry, I would he would take exception, he should not want ill usage to rid me of his trouble; as I live, custom has made me so acquainted with him, that I now begin to think him not so displeasing, as at first; and if he fall not out with me, I must with him, to secure my self. Sure (Aunt) he must find Sence and Reason absent, for when a Question knocks at his head, the Answer tells that there is no body at home; I ask'd him, th'other day, if he did not find a blemish in his understanding, and he sware a great Oath, Not he; I told him 'twas very strange, for Fool was so visible an eye-sore, that neither Birth nor Fortune eould reconcile to me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Faith, methinks his humour is good, and his purse will buy good company, and I can laugh and be merry with him sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, pray, Aunt, take him to your self, and see how merry we will be; I can laugh at any bodies Fool, but mine own.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By my troth, but that I have married one Fool already, you should not have him. Consider, he asks no portion, and yet will make a great joynture; a Fool with these conveniences, a kind loving Fool, and one that you may govern, makes no ill husband; Niece, there are other Arguments too, to bid a Fool welcome, which you will find without teaching; think of it, Niece; you may lay out your affection to purchase some dear wit, or judgement of the City, and repent, at leisure a good bargain, in this Fool.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Faith, Aunt, Fools are cheap in the Butchery, and dear in the Kitchin; they are such unsavory infipid things that there goes more charge to the sauce then the Fool is worth, ere a woman can confidently serve him, either to her bed or board; then if he be a loving Fool, he troubles all the world a days, and me all night.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Friendship-love, Madam, has a remedy for that.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: See if the air of this place has not enclin'd Secret to be a Baud already. No, Secret, you get no Gowns that way, Upon my word; if I marry, it shall be a Gentleman that has wit and honour, though he has nothing but a sword by his side; such a one naked is better then a Fool with all his Trappings, Bells and Baubles.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, as I live, he's a handsome fellow, and merry; mine is such a sad soul, and tells me stories of Lovers that dy'd in despair, and of the lamentable end of their Mistresses (according to the Ballad) and thinks to win me by Example.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Faith mine talks of nothing but how long he has lov'd me; and those that know me not, think I am old, and still finds new causes, (as he calls them) for his love; I ask'd him the other day if I chang'd so fast or no.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But what think'st thou, Secret; my Nephew dances well, and has a handsome house in the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Your Nephew? not I, As I live; he looks as if he would be woo'd; I'll warrant you, he'l never begin with a woman till he has lost the opinion of himself; But since you are so courteous, I'le speak to his friend, and let him know how you suffer for him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Him! marry God bless all good women from him; why, he talks as if the Dairy-maid and all her Cows could not serve his turn; then they wear such baudy-breeches, 'twould startle an honest woman to come in their company, for fear they should break, and put her to count from the fall of them; for I'le warrant, the year of the Lord would sooner out of her head then such a sight.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I am not such an enemy now to his humour as to your Nephews, he rails against our sex, and thinks by beating down the price of women to make us despair of Merchants; But if I had his heart-strings tied on a True-lovers-knot, I would so firk him till he found physick in a Rope.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: He's a scurvey tongu'd fellow, I'me sure of that; and if I could have got a staff, I had mark'd him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What did he do to thee, Secret?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, he swore, he had a better opinion of her then to think she had her Maiden-head; but if she were that Fool, and had preserv'd the toy, he swore he would not take the pains of fetching it, to have it; I confess, I would fain be reveng'd on them, because they are so blown up with opinion of their wit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live, my Nephew travels still; the sober honest Ned Wild will not be at home this moneth.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: What say you? will you abuse them and all the rest, and stand to my first Proposition?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, faith, if it be but to bury my servant, Sadd; for he cannot last above another Fall, and how, think you, will your servant take it?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Mine! oh God help me, mine's a healthy Fool, I would he were subject to pine and take things unkindly; there were some hope to be rid of him; for I'll undertake to use him as ill as any body.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live, I am easily resolv'd; for if I would marry, I know neither who nor what humour to chuse.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: By my troth, Madam, you are hard to please; else the Courtier might have serv'd turn.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Serve turn! Prithee what haste, Secret? that I should put my self to bed with one I might make a shift with; when I marry, thou shalt cry, I, marry, Madam; this is a husband without blushing wench, and none of your so-so husbands; yet he might half overcome my aversion, I confess.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Overcome! I think so, he might have won a City his way; for when he saw you were resolv'd he should not eat with you, he would set himself down as if he meant to besiege us, and had vow'd never to rise till he had taken us in; and because our sex forbad force, he meant to do it by famine; yet you may stay, and miss a better market; for hang me, I am of Secrets opinion; he had but two faults, a handsome fellow, and too soon deny'd.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he was a handsome fellow, and a civil, that I shall report him; for as soon as it was given him to understand; I desir'd he would come no more, I never saw him since, but by chance.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why did you forbid him?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: There were divers exceptions; But that which angred me then, was, he came with the Kings Letters Patents, as if he had been to take up a wife for his Majesties use.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Alas! was that all? why, 'tis their way at Court, a common course among them, and was it not one the King had a great care of? when my mother was alive, I had such a packet from the Court directed unto me, I bid them pay the Post, and make the fellow drink, which he took as ill as I could wish, and has been ever since such a friendly enemy.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, as I live, she was for the Captain too; his Scarfe and Feather won her heart.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, never flatter your self; for the Gentleman did not like you so well as to put you to the trouble of saying, no.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Lord, how I hated and dreaded that Scarfe and Buffc • at?

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Why, Mistress Pleasant, a Captain is an honourable Charge.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Prithee, Secret, name them no more, Colonel and Captain, Commissioner, Free-quarters, Ordance and Contribution; When Buff utters these words, I tremble and dread the sound; it frights me still when I do but think on them; Cuds body, they 're twigs of the old Rod (Wench) that whipt us so lately.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
I, I, and they were happy dayes, Wench, when the Captain was a lean, poor, humble thing, and the Souldier tame, and durst not come within the City, for fear of a Constable and a Whipping-post; they know the penal Statutes give no Quarter; Then Buff was out of countenance, and sculk'd from Ale-house to Ale-house, and the City had no Militia but the Sheriffs-men; In
those merry days, a Bailiff trode the streets with terror, when all the Chains in the City were rusty, but Mr. Sheriffs, when the people knew no evil but the Constable and his Watch; Now every Committee has as much power, and as little manners, and examines with as much ignorance, impertinence and authority, as a Constable in the Kings key.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: See, who's that so loud? People talking without.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: The men you talk'd of, newly come to Town.—

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. III.
div.stage: Enter Jack Constant, Will. Sadd, Jolly, and a Footman, they comb their heads, and talk.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Remember our covenants, get them that can, all friends; and be sure to dispatch the Plot, to carry them into the Country, lest the brace of new-come Monsieurs get them.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Those flesh-flies? I'll warrant thee from them, yet 'twas foolishly done of me to put on this gravity; I shall break out, and return to my self if you put me to a winters wooing.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: A little patience do's it; and I am content to suffer any thing till they're out of Town: Secret says, they think my pale face proceeds from my love.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Do's she? that shall be one hint to advance your designs, and my revenge; for so she be couzen'd I care not who do's it, for scorning me, who (by this hand) lov'd her parlously.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Sir, what shall I do with the horses?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Carry them to Brumsteds.

sp.speaker: Footm:
sp.p: What shall I do with your worships.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Mine? take him, hamstring him, kill him, any thing to make him away, lest having such a conveniency I be betray'd to another journey into the Country. Gentlemen, you are all welcome to my Country-house; Charing-cross, I am glad to see thee, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What? not reconcil'd to the Country yet?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: He was not long enough there to see the pleasure of it.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Pleasure? what is't call'd? walking or hawking, or shooting at Butts?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You found other pleasures, or else the story of the Meadow is no Gospel.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes, a pox upon the necessity. Here I could as soon have taken the Cow, as such a Milk-maid.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: The wine and meat's good, and the company.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
When, at a Tuesday-meeting the Country comes in to a match at two shillings Rubbers, where they conclude at dinner what shall be done this Parliament, railing against the Court and Pope, after the old Elizabeth-way of preaching, till they are drunk with zeal; and then the old Knight of the Shire from the boards end, in his Coronation breeches, vies clinches with a silenc'd Minister,
a Rogue that rail'd against the Reformation meerly to be eas'd of the trouble of preaching.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, As I live, now you are to blame, and wrong him, the man's a very able man.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: You'l be able to say so, one day, upon your wives report; I would he were gelt, and all that hold his opinion: By this good day, they get more souls then they save.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: And what think you of the Knights Son? I hope he's a fine Gentleman, when his green Suit, and his blew stockings are on; and the welcomest thing • live to Mrs. Abigail, but Tib and Tom in the Stock.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Who, Mr. Jeoffry? Hobinol the second; By this life, 'tis a very Veal, and he licks his Nose like one of them; By his discourse you'ld guess he had eaten nothing but Hay; I wonder he doth not go on all four too, and hold up his leg when he stales; he talks of nothing but the stable. The Coblers Black-bird at the corner has more discourse; he has not so much as the family-jest, which these Coridons use to inherit; I pos'd him in Booker's Prophesies, till he confest he had not master'd his Almanack yet.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But what was that you whisper'd to him in the Hall?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why, the Butler and I, by the intercession of March beer, had newly reconcil'd him to his Dads old Cod-piece Corslet, in the Hall; which, when his zeal was up, he would needs throw down, because it hung upon a Cross.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But what think you of my neighbour? I hope her charity takes you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes, and her old Waiting-womans devotion; she sigh'd in the Pew behind me; A Dutch Skippe • belches not so loud, or so sower; my Ladies miserable sinner, with the white 〈◊〉 she do's so squeeze out her prayers; and so wring out, Have 〈◊〉 upon us; I warrant her, she has a waiting-womans sting in her conscience; she looks like a dirty soul'd Baud.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Who is this, my Lady Freedom's woman that he describes?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: The same, the Independent Lady, I have promised to send her a Cripple or two by the next Carrier; her subject husband would needs shew me his house one morning; I never visited such an Hospital, it stunk like Bedlam, and all the servants were carrying Poultisses, Julips, and Glisters, and several Remedies for all Diseases, but his; The man sigh'd to see his Estate crumbling away; I counsell'd him either to give or take a ounce of Rats-bane, to cure his mind.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: She is my Cozen; but he made such a complaint to me, I thought he had married the Company of Surgeons Hall; for his directions to me for several things for his Wives use, were fitter for an pothecaries-shop then a Ladies Closet.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
I advised him to settle no Joynture, but her old Stills, and a Box of Instruments upon her; she hates a man with all his Limbs; a Wooden-leg, a Crutch and Fistula in Ano, wins her heart; her Gentleman-usher broke his leg last Dog-days, meerly
to have the honour to have her set it, a foul rank Rogue, and so full of salt humours, that he posed a whole Colledge of old Women with a Gangrene; which spoil'd the jest, and his ambling before my Lady, by applying a hand-saw to his gartring place; and now the Rogue wears booted Bed-staves, and destroys all the young ashes to make him legs.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: I never saw such a nasty affection; she would ha done well in the incurable; a Hand-maid to have waited on the Cripples.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: She converses with naked men, a •• handles all their members though never so ill affected, and calls the Fornication Charity; all her discourse to me was flat bawdry, which I could not chide, but spoke as flat as she, till she rebuked me, calling mine beastliness, and hers, Natural Philosophy; By this day, if I were to marry, I would as soon have chosen a drawn whore out of mine own Hospital, and cure the sins of her youth, as marry a she-Chirurgeon; one that for her sins in her first Husbands dayes cures all the crimes of her Sex in my time. I would have him call her Chiron, the Centaur's own Daughter; a Chirurgeon by Sire and Damm, Apollo's own Colt, she's red-hair'd too, like that bonny beast with the golden Mane and flaming taile.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: You had a long discourse with her, Jolly; what wa'st about?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I was advising her to be divorc'd, and marry the Man in the Almanack; 'twould be fine pastime for her to lick him whole.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: By this day, I never saw such a Mule as her Husband is, to bear with her madness; the house is a good house, and well furnished.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Yes, but 'tis such a sight to see great French Bedds full of found 〈◊〉 , sons of Batchelors, Priests Heirs, Bridewell Orphans; there they lie by dozens in a Bed, like sucking Rabbets in a dish, or a row of pins; and then they keep a whole Dairy of milch Whores to suckle them.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: She is succesful, and that spoils her, and makes her deaf to counsel; I bad him poyson two or three, to disgrace her; for the Vanity and Pride of their remedies make those Women more diligent then their Charity.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I asked him why he married her; and he confessed, if he had been sound he had never had her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: He confess'd, she cur'd him of three Claps before he married her.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p:
Yes, and I believe some other member (though then ill affected) pleaded more then his tongue; and the Rogue is like to find her business still, for he flies at all; My God, I owe thee thanks for many things; but 'tis not the least, I am not her Husband, nor a Country Gentleman, whither I believe you cannot easily seduce me again, unless you can perswade London to stand in the Country; To Hide Park, or so, I may venture upon your Lady-fair dayes, when the Filly Foales of fifteen come kicking in, with their Maines and tailes ty'd up in Ribbands, to see
their eyes roule and neigh, when the Spring makes their blood prick them; so far I am with you by the way of a Country Gentleman and a Beer-drinker.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: For all this dislike, Master Jolly; your greatest acquaintance lies amongst Country Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I, at London, there your Country Gentlemen are good Company, where to be seen with them is a kind of credit; I come to a Mercers shop in your Coach; Boy, call your Master; he comes bare, I whisper him, Do you know the Constants and the Sadds of Norfolk? yes, yes, he replyes, and strokes his beard; they are good Men cry I, yes, yes; No more, cut me off three sutes of Sattin, he does it, and in the delivery whispers, Will these be bound? pish, drive on Coachman, speak with me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: What then? why, come again next day.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: And what if the Country Gentleman will not be bound?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Then he must fight.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: I would I had known that before I had sign'd your Bond, I would have set my sword sooner then my Seal to it.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Why, if thou repent there's no harm done, fight rather then pay it.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Why, do you think I dare not fight?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Yes, but I think thou hast more wit then to fight with me; for if I kill thee, 'tis a fortune to me, and others will sign in fear; and if thou should'st kill me, any body that knows us would swear 'twere very strange, and cry, there's Gods just judgement now upon that lewd youth, and thou procur'st his hang-mans place at the rate of thy Estate.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: By this hand, he is in the right; and for mine I meant to pay when I sign'd; hang it, never put good fellowes to say, prithee give me a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: 'Tis true, 'tis a good ganty way of begging; yet, for being kill'd, if I refuse it, would there were no more danger in the Widows unkindness, then in your fighting; I would not mistrust my design.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Why I, there's a point now in nicity of Honour, I should kill you for her; for, you know I pretended first; and it may be if I had writ sad lines to her, and hid my self in my Cloak, and haunted her Coach, it may be in time she would have sought me; not I, by this hand, I'll not trouble my self for a Wench, and married Widowes are but Customary authoriz'd Wenches.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Being of that Opinion, how can'st thou to think of marrying one?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Why, faith, I know not, I thought to rest me, for I was run out of breath with pleasure, and grew so acquainted with si • , I would have been good (for variety;) in these thoughts, 'twas my fortune to meet with this Widow, handsome, and of a clear Fame.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Did'st love her?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p:
Yes, faith? I had Love, but not to the disease that makes
men sick; and I could have lov'd her still, but that I was angry to have her refuse me for a fault I told her of my self, so I went no more.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Did she forbid you but once?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faith, I think I slipt a fair Opportunity, a handsome wench, and three thousand pounds per annum in certainty, besides the possibility of being saved.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Which now you think desperate? Widow and Pleasant looking out at a window.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: That is you; Cross or Pile, will you have him yet or no?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Peace, observe them.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faith no, I do not despair, but I cannot resolve.

div.stage: Enter Wild, Careless, and the Captain, going in haste, he comes in at the middle Door.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Who are those?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Captain, whither in such haste? what defeated? call you this a retreat, or a flight from your friends?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Your Nephew, and his Governour, and his Friend! here will be a Scene, sit close, and we may know the secret of their hearts.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: They have not met yet since they return'd, I shall love this bay window.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Prithee let me go, there's mischief a Boyling; and if thou shak'st me once more thou wilt Jumble a lye together I have been hammering this hour.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A pox upon you, a studying lies?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, then they are no lies, but something in the praise of an old Ladies Beauty, what do you call that?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Who are those?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: I'st not the Captain, and my Friend? They spie each other.

div.stage: Jolly salutes them, then he goes to the Captain to embrace him, the Captain stands in a French posture, and slides from his old way of embracing.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ned Wild? Tom Careless? What ayl'st thou, dost thou scorn my embraces?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I see you have never been abroad, els you would know how to put a value upon those whose careful observation brought home the most Exquisite Garb and Courtship that Paris could sell us.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: A pox on this fooling, and leave off Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why then agreed, off with our masks, and let's embrace They embrace. like the old knot.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faith, say, where have you spent these three years time? in Our Neighbour France? or have you ventur'd o're the Alps, to see the seat of the Caesars?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: And can tell us (Ignorant, doom'd to walk upon our own Land) how large a seat the Goddess fix'd her flying Trojans in.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and have seen, and drunk (perhaps) of Tybers famous stream.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: And have been where Aeneas buried his Trumpeter, and his Nurse; Tom looks as if he had suck'd the one, and had a Battel sounded by the other, for Joy to see our Nation ambitious not to be understood or known when they come home.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So, now I'me welcome home, this is freedom, and these are Friends, and with these I can be merry; for Gentlemen, you must give me leave to be free to.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: So you will spare us miserable men, condemn'd tc London, and the Company of a Michelmas Term, and never travel'd those Countries that set Mountains on fire a purpose to light us to our lodging.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why this is better then to stay at home, and lie by hearsay, wearing out your selves and Fortunes like your cloathes, to see her that hates you for being so fine, then appearing at a Play drest like some part of it, while the Company admire the Mercers and the Taylors work, and swear they have done their parts to make you fine Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Then leap out of your Coach, and throw your Cloak over your shoulder, the Casting Nets to catch a Widow, while we have seen the world, and learn'd her Customs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and return'd perfect Mounsieurs.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p:
Yes, even to their diseases; I confess my Ignorance; I cannot amble, nor ride like S. George at Waltham.
The Captain has a patch over his Nose.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Yet, upon my Conscience, he may be as welcome with a trot, as the other with his pace; and faith, Jack, (to be a little free) tell me, dost thou not think thou hadst been as well to pass here, with that English Nose thou carryedst hence, as with the French tongue thou hast brought home?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is an Accident, and to a Souldier 'tis but a scar; 'tis true, such a sign upon Mr. Jolly's face had been as ill as a Red Cross, and Lord have mercy upon us, at his lodging door, to have kept women out of Court.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: For ought you know of the Court.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I know the Court, and thee, and thy use, and how you serve but as the handsomest movables, a kind of Implement above stairs, and look much like one of the old Court Servants in the hangings.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But that they move, and look fresher, and your Apparel more Modern.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Yet, faith, their Office is the same, to adorn the Room, and be gaz'd on: Alas! hee's sad, Courage man, these riding cloaths will serve thee at the latter day.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Which is one of their grievances, for nothing troubles them more then to think they must appear in a foul winding sheet, and come undrest.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I am glad to find you know the Court; we know a Traveller too, especially when he is thus chang'd and Exchang'd, as your Worships, both in Purse and Person, and
have brought home forreign visages and Inscriptions.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why that's their perfection, their ambition to have it said, there go those that have profitably observ'd the vices of other Countreys, and made them their own; and the faults of several Nations, at their return, are their Parts.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Why there's Jack Careless, he carried out as good stable manners as any was in Suffolk, and now he is return'd with a shrug, and a trick to stand crooked, like a skirvy Bow unbent, and looks as if he would maintain Oyl and Sallads against a Chyne of Beef; I knew a great Beast of this kind, it haunted the Court much, and would scarcely allow us (fully reduc'd to Civility) for serving up Mutton in whole joynts.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What, silent?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Faith, the Captain is in a study.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Do, do, Conn the Rivers and Towns perfectly, Captain; thou may'st become Intelligencer to the People, and lie thy two sheets a week in Corrantoes too.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And could you not make Friends at Court, to get their Pictures cut ugly, in the Corner of a Map, like the old Navigators.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Wee'le see, wee'le see.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'le interrupt them; Servant, you're welcome to Town; how now, Nephew? what, dumb? where are all our travel'd tongues?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Servant! who doth she mean? By this hand, I disclaim the Title.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Captain, Secret has taken Notes, and desires you would instruct her in what concerns a waiting Woman, and an Old Lady.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Very good, yet this shall not save your Dinner.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, while you are in this humor I'le not sell your Companies; and though Master Jolly be incensed, I hope he will do me the favour to dine with me.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Faith, Lady, you mistake me if you think I am afraid of a widow; for I would have the world know I dare meet her any where, but at Bed.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No more Aunt, wee'le come; and if you will give us good meat, weel bring good humors, and good stomacks. Widow shuts the Curtain.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this day I'le not dine there, they take a pleasure to raise a spirit that they will not lay, I'le to Banks's.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Pox forbid it, you shall not break Company, now you know what we are to do after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I will consent, upon condition you forbid the spiritual Non-sence the age calls Platonick Love.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I must away too; But I'le be there at Dinner, you will joyn in a Plot after dinner.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Any thing, Good, Bad, or Indifferent, for a Friend and Mirth.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I must go and prevent the Rogues mischief, with the Old Lady.

div.head: ACT. II. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter Jolly, and the old Lady Love-all.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: AWay, unworthy, false, ingrateful; with what Brow dar'st thou come again into my sight, knowing how unworthy you have been, and how false to love?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: No, 'tis you are unworthy, and deserve not those truths of Love I have pay'd here; else you would not believe ev'ry report that Envy brings, and condemn, without hearing me, whom you have so often try'd and found faithful.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Yes, till I too credulous had pity on your tears; till I had mercy you durst not be false.

sp.speaker: Joil.
sp.p: Nor am not yet.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What dost thou call False? is there a treachery beyond what thou hast done; when I had given my Fame, my Fortune, my self, and my husbands honour, all in one Obligation, a sacrifice to that Passion; which thou seem'st to labour with despair of, to tell and Brag of a conquest o're a Woman, fool'd by her Passion, and lost in her love to thee, unworthy;—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: By this Day, 'tis as false as he that said it; hang him, son of a Batchelour; a slave that envying my Fortune in such a happiness as your love, and chast embraces, took this way to ruine it; Come, dry your Eyes, and let the guilty weep; if I were guilty I durst as soon approach a Constable drunk, as come here; you know I am your slave.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You swore so, and honour made me leave to triumph over your miseries.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Do you repent that I am happy? if you do, command my death.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay, never weep, nor sit sadly, I am Friends, so you will onely talk and discourse; for 'tis your company I onely covet.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, you cannot forgive, because you have injur'd me; 'tis right womans Justice; Accuse first, and harder to reconcile when they are guilty, then when they are Innocent, or else you would not turn from me thus.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You know your youth hath a strong power over me; Turn those bewitching Eyes away; I cannot see them with safety of mine honour.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Come you shall not hide your Face, there's a Charm in it against those that come burnt with unchast fires; for let but your Eyes or Nose drop upon his heart it would burn it up, or quench it strait.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No Cogging, you have injur'd me; and now though my Jolly kisses her, and she shoves him away with her mouth. love plead, I must be deaf, my honour bids me; for you will not fear again to prove unworthy when you find I am so easie to forgive—Why, you will not be uncivil.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: So, the storm is lay'd, I must have those Pearls—she shov'd me away with her mouth, I'le to her again.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Where are you? what do you take me for? why you Still as he offers to touch her, she starts as if he pluckt up her coats. will not be uncivil?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Uncivil! By thy chaste self, I cannot, Chick; thou hast such a terror, such a guard in those eyes, I dare not approach thee, nor can I gaze upon so much fire; Prithee, Sirrah, let me hide me from their power here.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You presume upon the weakness of our sex; what shall I say or do? Tyrant Love!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: There's a charm in those Pearls; pull them off; if they have a Frost in them, let me wear them, and then we are both safe.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I would you had taken them sooner, I had then been innocent, and might with whiteness have worn my love which I shall ne're out-live.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Dear, do not too fast pour in my joys, lest I too soon reach my heaven.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Be gone then, lest we prove (having gain'd that height) this sad truth in Love; The first minute after noon is night.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Part now? The Gods forbid; take from me first this load of joys you have thrown upon me; for 'tis a burthen harder to bear then sadness; I was not born till now, this my first night in which I reap true bliss.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: No, no; I would it had been your first night, then your falshood had not given argument for these tears; and I hate my self to think I should be such a foolish fly, thus again to approach your dangerous flame.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Come, divert these thoughts; I'll go see your Closet.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: No, no, I swear you shall not.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: You know, I am going out of Town for two days.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: When you return, I'll shew it you; you will forget me else when you are gone, and at Court.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Can your love endure delays? or shall business thee from hence remove? these were your own Arguments; come, you shall shew it me.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Nay, then I perceive what unworthy way your love would find; Ye Gods, are all men false?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
As I live, you shall stay; come, you ought to make me
He pulls her Bodkin, that is tied in a piece of black Bobbin.
He pulls her, and says this. amends for slandring of me; Hang me, if ever I told; and he that reports it is the damn'dst Rogue in a Country, Come, I say.—

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Ah! As I live, I will not, I have sworn; do not pull me, I will not be damn'd, I have sworn.—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: As I live, I'll break your Bodkin then, a weeping Tyrant! Come; by this good day, you shall be merciful.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Why, you will not be uncivil; you will not force me, will you? As I live, I will not.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Nay, and you be wilful, I can be stubborn too. He pulls still.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Hang me, I'll call aloud, why Nan! nay, you may force me; But, As I live, I'll do nothing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Pox upon you, are you earth'd? The Rogue has got her Neck-lace of Pearl; but I hope he will leave the Rope to hang me in, how the pox came they so great? I must have some trick to break his neck, else the young Rogue will work me out; 'tis an excellent old Lady, but I dare not call her so; yet would she were young enough to bear, we might do some good for our heirs, by leaving such a charitable brood behind; she's a woman after the first kind; 'tis but going in to her and you may know her; then she'l oblige so readily, and gives with greater thankes then others receive, takes it so kindly to be courted. I am now to oblige her (as she calls it) by professing young Wilds love, and desiring an assurance; she's sensible of his sufferings, which though it be false, and beyond my Commission, yet the hopes of such a new young thing that has the vogue of the Town, for handsomest, 'twill so tickle her age, and so blow up her vanity, to have it said, He is in love with her, and so endear her to me for being the means that the Parsons malice will be able to take no root;—She comes, I must not be seen.—

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Give me that Letter I'll swear, you shall not read it.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Take it, I'll away, What time shall I call you, in the evening? there's a Play at Court to night.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I would willingly be there, but your Ladies are so censorious, and malitious to us young Ladies, in the Town, especially to me, because the Wits are pleas'd to afford me a visit, or so; I could be content else to be seen at Court; Pray what humour is the Queen of? the Captain of her Guard I know.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: The Queen? Who's that knocks at the back-door.— The Captain Knocks.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Smooth my Band, I know not, go down that way, and look you be not false; if you should be false, I'll swear, I should spoil my self with weeping.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Farewell, in the evening I'll call you.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Who's there? Captain? Where have you been all this while; I might sit alone, I see, for you, if I could not find conversation in Books. She takes a book in her hand and sits down.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, friends newly come to Town engag'd me, and my stay was civility rather then desire, what Book's that?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I'll swear he was a Witch that writ it; for he speaks my thoughts as if he had been within me; the Original, they say, was French.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh, I know it, 'tis the accomplish'd Woman, Your self, he means by this, while you are your self.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Indeed, I confess, I am a great friend to conversation, if we could have it without suspition; But the world's so apt to judge, that 'tis a prejudice to our honour now to salute a man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Innocence, Madam, is above opinion, and your fame's too great to be shook with whispers.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: You are ever civil, and therefore welcome; pray, what news is there now in Town? for I am reclus'd here; unless it be yours, I receive no visits; and I'll swear, I charg'd the Wench to day not to let you in; I wonder she let you come.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, if it had been my own business I should not have ventur'd so boldly; But the necessity that forces me to come concerns my friend, against whom if your mercy be now bounded with those strict ties of honour, and cold thoughts which I have ever found guard your heart, My friend, a young and handsome man, is lost, is lost in his prime, and falls like early blossoms; But methinks you should not prove the envious frost to destroy this young man, this delicate young man, that has whole bundles of Boys in his Breeches; yet if you be cruel, he and they dye, as useless as open Arses gathered green. She must be earnest in her looks all the time he speaks; desrous to know who he speaks of.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Good Captain, out with the particular, what way can my charity assist him; you know by experience I cannot be cruel, remember how I fetch'd you out of a swoond, and laid you in my own bed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That act preserved a life, that has always been labour'd in your service; and I dare say, your charity here will find as fruitful a gratitude.

sp.speaker: Love-all,
sp.p: But, I hope, he will not be so uncivil as you were; I'll swear, I could have hang'd you for that Rape, if I would have follow'd the Law; but I forgave you upon condition you would do so again; but what's this young man you speak of?

sp.speaker: Capt,
sp.p: Such is my love to you and him, that I cannot prefer mine own particular before your contents; else I'de have poyson'd him ere I'de have brought him to your house.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Why, I pray?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Because, he's young, handsome, and sound parts; that I'me sure will ruine me here.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: His love may make all these beauties, else I have an honour will defend me against him, were he as handsome as young Wild.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why I, there it is; that one word has remov'd all my fears and jealousies with a despair; for that's the man whose Love, Life and Fortune, lies at your feet; and if you were single, by lawful ways he would hope to reach what now he despairs of.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Let him not despair, Love is a powerful pleader, and youth and beauty will assist him; and if his love be noble I can meet it; for there's none that sacrifices more to friendship-love, then I.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
My friends interest makes me rejoyce at this; dare you trust me to say this to him, though it be not usual, pray speak; Nay, you are so long still a resolving to be kind: Remember, charity is as great a vertue as chastity, and greater, if we will hear nature plead; for the one may make many Maids, the other can but preserve one: But I know you will be perswaded, let be my importunity
that prevail'd, shall I bring him hither one evening?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Why do you plead thus? pray be silent, and when you see him, tell him he has a seat here, and I— She turns away,

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Out with it, what is't? shall he call you Mistress? and his Platonick?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Away, away; Me?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No niceness, is't a match?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Lord, would I were as worthy as willing (pray tell him so) he shall find me one of the humblest Mistresses that ever he was pleas'd to honour with his affections.

sp.speaker: Capt,
sp.p: Dare you write this to him, and honour me with bearing it? I confess, I am such a friend to friendship-love too that I would even bring him on my back to a mid-nights meeting.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: If you will stay here, I'll go in and write it.— She's going out and he calls her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Madam, I forgot to ask your Ladiship one Question.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: What was't?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There hapned a business last night betwixt Mr. Wild and one Jolly, a Courtier that brags extreamly of your favour; I swear, if it had not been for friends that interpos'd themselves there had been mischief, for Mr. Wild was extream zealous in your cause.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Such a Rascal I know; Villain, to bring my name upon the Stage, for a subject of his quarrels, I'll have him cudgeld.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And I'll swear, he deserv'd it; for the quarrel ended in a Bet of a Buck-hunting-nag, that sometime to day he would bring a Neck-lace and chain of Pearl of yours (not stoln, but freely given) to witness his power.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Did the vain Rascal promise that?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, but we laught at it.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: So you might; and, as I live, if the Neck-lace were come from stringing I'de send them both to Mr. Wild, to wear as a favour, to assure him I am his, and to put the vain slave out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I marry, such a timely favour were worth a dozen Letters, to assure him of your Love, and remove all the doubts the others discourse may put into his head; and faith I'de send him the chain now, and in my Letter promise him the Neck-lace, he'l deserve such a favour.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I'll go in and fetch it immediately, will you favour me to deliver it?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll wait upon your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I'll swear you shall not go in, you know I forswore She goes and he follow's her, she turns and bids him stay. being alone with you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hang me, I'll go in; do's my Message deserve to wait an Answer at the Door?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I, but you'l be naught.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: O, ne're trust me if I break.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: If you break some such forfeit you'l lose; Well, come in for once.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You are so suspitious.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I'll swear, I have reason for't, you are such another man.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: IS he gone?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Yes, he's gone to the old Ladies, high with mischief.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Fare him well, easie Fool, how the Trout strove to be tickled, and how does this Ring become me? Ha! they are S • s playes with a Wedding Ring upon ber finger. fine kind of things these Wedding Rings.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Besides the good custom of putting so much Gold in 'em, they bring such conveniencies along.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Why I, now I have but one to please; and if I please him, who dares offend me? and that Wife's a fool that cannot make her Husband one.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Nay, I am absolutely of Opinion, it was fit for you to marry; but whether he be a good Husband or no.

sp.speaker: Want.
